  • 11Recommend

Erik Painter

Bremerton, WA February 23, 2016

The research is good but as is often the case the reporting includes some poor information that undermines the message. To include Any data on Annapolis flooding is highly distorting of the real rise in sea levels. The whole Chesapeake Bay is one of the areas on the east coast that is subsiding the very most. That subsidence is unrelated to sea level rise. It is the result of post glacial isostatic adjustment. The NY city area and north are rebounding and getting higher, thus reducing the apparent actual sea rise. However, south of the glacial mass the land was higher (like when you push down on a mattress) and is now subsiding at a fast rate. Also the source of sediment has been cut off. The result is that the whole Bay area is sinking and will keep sinking.
Data where it will be more clear and important will be from areas that were never near glaciation. For example the WHOLE west coast from Portland to Baja California. To look at anywhere in the NE of the east coast is basically responsible. The data from Key West is a clear signal. Annapolis or Boston is not. Further complicating east coast sea temperature is the Gulf stream which moves south to north bringing warmer (and therefore higher) water. On the west coast the currents move north to south.
The Times really needs to be less NE oriented in coverage in this area. I regularly see shock expressed at minor increases in tide heights on the east coast. Here in the NW we regularly have tidal swings of 14 feet.

  • Flag
  • 3Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Rupert Patton

Huntsville AL February 23, 2016

I have an experiment for everyone across the country who is over 50 years old to do. Go to the place where you used to visit the beach when you were a kid. Go to the hotel, or lodge or public pier and stand and look at the water's edge. See if it looks any different than it did when you were a kid. Is the shoreline any closer? Get out that old black and white of the pier, accounting for high tide v low tide, are the same pylons under water? And about the same amount? For those who have lived 50+ years in New York go down and look at the shoreline wall at Battery park, or Liberty Island, or the rock supports for the Brooklyn Bridge, pull out the old photos. How much higher does the water appear than in the old pictures? Those pictures were over 4+ decades ago. If the water has been rising for 100 years at the highest rate in 3 mellinnia don't you think things should be a lot more different than they were 50 or 70 years ago when these were built? In 1992 the first IPCC report predicted average sea level rises of 6 cm per decade. That means in 25 years they would rise 20 cm, or 6 inches. As we sit here in 2016, 24 years later they have risen just shy of 6 cm total, only 40% of what was predicted. Why??? If over the last half century us beach goers haven't really noticed any significant change, and if over the last quarter century the observed rise was less than half of what climate experts predicted, is it so unreasonable to be skeptical of their dire future?

Dean

West February 23, 2016

It is not popular to say but, from what I can see, we tipped over the edge sometime in the last half of the last century with uncontrolled human population growth. What scientists thought would happen in several centuries gradually became what would happen in a century or two then became what would happen at the end of this century and now it has become what will happen by mid century. The trend is not good.

It is not just an increase in sea levels but more moisture in the air, changes in wind patterns, acidification of the oceans, spread of insects like mosquitoes and pine beetles, contamination of fresh water aquifers, drought and forest fires and who knows what else. That is it after all. We do not know what else.

A small minority of humans seems to be concerned. Will there be a gradual sense of panic? I do not live on the Gulf Coast or other flood prone area and I do not understand how people are so calm.

Phil N

Roseland, NJ February 23, 2016

Here's a test for all you "the ice is melting and the seas are rising" alarmists.
Get yourself a big glass see through bowl and fill it about 80% of the way to the top with water. Then, take a bunch of ice cubes and put them in there and then immediately get a sharpie and mark on the side of the bowl the height of the water.
The ice floats, right? A small portion of the ice is higher than the water level, right? Imagine in your mind if you can that this is a model of the Artic Ocean.
Now, wait a while for all of the ice cubes to melt.
Did the level of the water change? NO IT DIDN'T !!!!! It's call displacement. Look it up and learn something.
And if you're telling me that the ice sitting on top of the continent of Antartica is melting with an average annual air temp of something like -10 and running off into the sea then I have a bridge to sell you across the Grand Canyon.

Daniel Steele

Port Ludlow, WA February 23, 2016

A little info for the energy reality deniers:
Diesel has an Energy density of 36 MegaJoules/Liter & a Specific Energy of 48 MegaJoules/Kilogram. The best rechargeable Lithium-ion batteries, less than 2.6 MJ/L & less than 0.88 MJ/Kg, respectively. For Uranium the numbers are 1,540,000 MJ/L & 80,000,000 MJ/kg.

Ari Shinozaki

San Jose February 23, 2016

As a former scientist, and for the last 20 years in business leadership and consulting service to various large corporations, I find various digs at the "numerous" and "rich" scientists both amusing and sad, frustrating and disappointing. Amusing in that my company currently employs college graduates who get paid far more than many academics. As fine as these people are, these employees are certainly not uniformly smarter, more productive, or bring a greater contribution to society. Sad in that the number of scientists in climate and other disciplines is relatively minor, and income of most in science modest to meager. Factor in the multiple years as a grad student learning the trade and craft, it's not a path for anyone who solely wants a job. To those who criticize all of science as monied gold diggers, you are sadly misinformed.

Frustrating in that climate skeptics often dismiss the science with the ad hominem attack on the scientific community. Often supporting their position in their limited choice of scientific facts they choose to listen to, which are often filtered only by the outcome they desire and not critically weighed as scientists are asked to.

It's a disappointing state of affairs as the skeptics are loud in their irreverence and sloppy thinking. I hope others who have had their lives both in the world of science and that of business will counter this type of thinking with appropriate financial and leadership support.

Ehkzu

Palo Alto, CA February 23, 2016

What's interesting about this comment is its underlying assumptions:

1. That climate science isn't real science, and that climate scientists are only in it for the money.

2. That every national science association--both general and in every scientific specialty--is lying about climate change, despite having no financial gain in doing so for the 99% of national science associations that aren't about climate science in particular.

2. That 196 countries' governments are lying about climate change so they can get more money from taxpayers.

3. That it's OK for Repubican-controlled politicians to oppose doing anything about climate change because Democrats drive cars.

4. That you can conceal your own lack of education by scoffing at those who know more than you do, in the grand American tradition of anti-intellectualism noted by Alexis deTocqueville nearly 200 years ago.

5. That since the author of these comments is selfish and short-sighted and doesn't care in the slightest what happens to his grandchildren, that everyone else is equally selfish and shortsighted--otherwise it might force the author to confront his own disregard for those he pretends to care about.

In Herman Melville's novella Billy Budd (made into a great movie in the 60s with Peter Ustinov and Terence Stamp), there's an archtypal Republican character in the form of a Lt. Claggart, whose total cynicism about human nature was challenged by Billy Budd's goodness and kindness, so he destroys Billy...

Eugene Gorrin

Union, NJ February 23, 2016

We need the EPA's Clean Power Plan ("CPP") now.

The CPP has everything to do with limiting carbon pollution that causes climate change. Climate change is already harming human health. Burning fossil fuels is the #1 source of heat-trapping carbon pollution that causes climate change. The added benefit of CPP is trimming other nasty health-harming pollution emitted at the same time as carbon pollution.

There's an enormous body of scientific evidence that connects the dots between climate change and our health.

There's people's personal experience - with 2015 the hottest year ever recorded globally, and 15 of the 16 hottest years ever having occurred in the 21st century. In recent years, we've witnessed (or lived through) extreme heat, precipitation extremes from drought to heavy downpours, historic wildfires, emerging infectious diseases, sea level rise and coastal storms flooding cities and towns.

Two-thirds of Americans are in favor of the US taking action to limit climate change.

With the CPP, we can move away from the dirty fossil fuels that are driving climate change and shift to smarter, cleaner, healthier ways to power our future without endangering our planet and our future.

Susan Anderson

is a trusted commenter Boston February 23, 2016

"It turns out the climate change deniers were right: There isn’t 97% agreement among climate scientists."

"more than 99.9% ...

"James L. Powell, director of the National Physical Sciences Consortium, reviewed more than 24,000 peer-reviewed papers on global warming published in 2013 and 2014."

"Powell, a member of the National Science Board under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush"

"Powell argues that acceptance of man-made global warming has grown. The author of a new Columbia University Press book on scientific revolutions used an online database to compile a mountain of global warming papers published in the last two years."

"He also tried a different approach than the earlier studies. Rather than search for explicit acceptance of anthropomorphic global warming, Powell searched for explicit rejection. All the papers in the middle ... weren’t neutral on the subject — they were settled on it."

"The results include work from nearly the entire population of working climate scientists — close to 70,000 scientists, often sharing their byline with three or four other authors. They also include a dwindling opposition: Powell could find only four solitary authors who challenged the evidence for human-caused global warming.

"That’s a rate of one dissenting voice for every 17,000 agreeing scientists, and it’s not a strong voice."

http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/how-climate-change-deniers-got-it-very-wrong

Tom

Virginia February 23, 2016

"He also tried a different approach than the earlier studies. Rather than search for explicit acceptance of anthropomorphic global warming, Powell searched for explicit rejection. All the papers in the middle[, he figured], weren’t neutral on the subject — they were settled on it."

Are you serious? He counts among those who are not settled on the question of anthropogentic global warming (APG) only those who explicitly reject the theory in a journal paper, and "he figured" everyone else, skeptics included, are "settled" in favor of the theory. "He figured"? Not a very scientific approach, but the type of nonsense skeptics have come to expect.

And your omission of the telling words "he figured" is blatantly disengenuous. And disengenuously parroting junk science is another thing skeptics have come to expect from global warming zealots.

Being skeptical, or as yet unconvinced, does not mean you reject the theory. One can also believe that the activities of mankind have affected climate but also believe this effect is insignificant as a practical matter.

Rupert Patton

Huntsville AL February 23, 2016

Susan, since apparently all you can do is read MSNBC articles where climate scientists pat each other on the back because they all agree on their predictions and models, let's do an experiment and see if we can turn you into a scientist and let you draw your own conclusions. First don't read MSNBC, and don't read FOXNEWS either, instead read the first IPCC report from 1992. The summary will suffice for time. In it you will find a prediction of global temp rises of 0.3 deg C/ decade and Sea Level rises of 6 cm/ decade. Now go to NOAA/ GISS and look at their charts plotting actual temp rises in the last 24 years (that's 2.4 decades) and you'll find it about .42 deg C hotter and Sea level about 5.9 cm higher. Each of those is about half of what the climate experts predicted. Now put on your objective scientist hat and explain, does it make scientific sense that if 97% of the models overestimated observed temps by an average of at least 50% that 99.99% of scientists should still feel they are all correct? And if they do, could it be that something else is convincing them. Like all that self back patting? How many other areas does being less than half right actually increase your confidence that your future predictions, based on the same models, will be right? I can't think of any? Can you??

Daniel Steele

Port Ludlow, WA February 23, 2016

Carbon Dioxide (CO2) & Photosynthesis are the foundation of Life on Earth. Plants/plankton turn Sunlight/CO2 into Food/Oxygen. Neither animal nor blade of grass would exist, absent CO2. Increasing CO2 lengthens growing seasons & encourages plants to move higher in altitude & Latitudes; just as it helps to shrink deserts, plants using water more efficiently. Rising temperatures also lengthen growing seasons, help babies of nearly every species, increase net rainfall & save lives; because cold kills. The Earth is greener, more fertile & life sustaining than it was 40 years ago.

NYT Pick

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 23, 2016

"I find it amazing that people are still buying and driving huge gas guzzling SUV's to run errands around town. Why?"

It might comfort you to learn that many who feel projections of sea-level rise actually agree with you. I do my fair share – more, I think – to cut down on the use of carbon fuels. That doesn't mean, though, that I'm required to ignore the inescapable fact that hypotheses about sea-level rise don't seem to be borne out by actual measurements. I've read projections that San Francisco sea levels would rise by 8 feet (or by as little as 3 feet -- never less) in this century. Yet in fact sea levels have risen only an inch so far (half an inch in Los Angeles), and we've now got 15 years under our belts in this century.

One can do one's part to save the environment and nevertheless have serious doubts about some of the shoot-from-the-hip projections of environmental disaster that get bandied about these days.

  • Flag
  • 6Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 23, 2016

"I mean, I know some people think "science" is just someone's "opinion", but seriously."

A hypothesis is just an educated guess – an "opinion" if you prefer. By itself, a hypothesis is not "science." It becomes "science" when it's tested and found to be correct.

That's not happening with many climate change hypotheses. That's the point. Before this century began, for example, many scientists predicted very large sea level rises in San Francisco – 8 feet in many cases, and no less than 3 feet that I can recall.

We've now got 15 years under our belts in this century, and sea level has actually risen about an inch here in San Francisco, and about a half an inch in Los Angeles. Should we just keep on accepting projections of an 8-foot rise as accurate? When, if ever, do you think we should start paying attention to actual measurements?

  • Flag
  • 3Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

mjohns

Bay Area CA February 23, 2016

Al Gore did no such thing. East Antarctica has not melted in millions of years.
Predictions of global warning impacts have largely underestimated the impacts.
This is true for several reasons:
1. Scientists, and science work largely by consensus--this means that extreme positions are trimmed until or unless lots of additional evidence supports them.
2. Predicting impacts includes predicting how much greenhouse gas will be released. Global releases have increased very rapidly despite the obvious threats from release. The predicted new releases have assumed greenhouse gas release limitations (as Western Europe has done). Greenhouse gas release has been under-predicted--so the effects have also been under-predicted. Multiple scenarios are now included.
3. Sea level rise has been, and is, the least well predicted impact of warming. This is because the effects of global warming on sea level over centuries is pretty well understood--but the rate of rise is not well understood. This is partly because the rate of warming now is at least 10 times faster than any of the paleo-climate records show. It is also partly because the risks of sudden rises if, for example, the west Antarctic ice sheet collapses (as is now strongly suspected) are not well enough understood. The consensus estimates still ignore sheet collapse--but still were updated to at least 3 feet from 1 to 1 1/2 feet. 3 feet is really a best case estimate.

  • Flag
  • 6Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Further, we can anticipate the deterioration of the food supply as the oceans acidify and become lifeless. To allow this to happen would be utterly stupid. I believe the scientific and engineering communities of the World must be restructured to head off the certain collapse of civilization.

We can start by organizing an international effort to launch solar generators to geosynchronous orbit to generate very cheap electricity for the world. We know how to do this and only need an international sponsor.

With cheap electricity we can made diesel, gasoline and jet fuel from air and water. We know how and this can be the province of our existing hydrocarbon industries that can preserve the wealth of their investors.

Finally, we should develop mass transit using superconducting Maglev invented by Drs. James Powell and Gordon Danby of New York.

Just in case we fail to head off flooding, Powell and his brother have invented a frozen coastal barriers to protect our major cities from surges.

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 23, 2016

"I hope your math is correct. Because if it isn't we all die."

We all die if my math isn't correct?

First of all, I'm not using any "math." I'm just citing actual data, which shows a steady (and quite low – indeed, in some places "negative") rate of sea level rise over the past 25 years or so – and no increase in the rate of sea level rise. Second, even if I were reporting "math" and it were incorrect, would it follow that "we all die?" Doesn't that require us to assume YOUR math is correct? Is it?

I'm not "denying" anything – "science" or otherwise. All I'm doing is pointing out that science involves a continual process of hypothesizing, testing hypotheses with actual measurement, and revising hypotheses if the measurements don't support them.

It's not "science" to present some hypothesis and demand that others simply accept it as proven fact, before any data has been collected. And after data has been collected, it's not "science" to shout down, as "deniers," those who simply point out that actual measurements don't seem to be supporting your hypothesis.

In the "science" world, at some point hypothesizing gives way to measurement. If actual measurements don't support a hypothesis, the hypothesizer is expected to revise his hypothesis – not to shout down his opponents by labeling them all "deniers" for simply pointing to actual data.

  • Flag
  • 2Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

hy dinout

Atlanta February 23, 2016

Hey Justin from an old Reed Hall, UGA friend! Being a UGA grad it hurts to point to Ga Tech for a great resource on this topic. I warn you that both sides of this argument will have to admit things that they would rather not (such as the worthlessness of averaging sea temps and land temps for anything meaningful due to differences in the heat capacity of these two substances. Dry desert sand is 4 times as volatile as ocean water so recording a change as equal will lead to huge miscalculations and projections.) It is a web site run by GA Tech's former chair of the School of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences and her goal is to admit where the science is lacking, admit where the research is rock solid and most of all admit what we really do not know yet.

The only way to get real solutions that actually impact the problems projected is to deal with facts openly. The absolute transparent truth shouldn't scare those who are really concerned with fixing a problem rather than pushing an agenda. Both sides have been pushing agendas. this site and its contents really makes one stop and think (even one who was a denier). Here is the link to the site. https://judithcurry.com/2016/02/10/are-land-sea-temperature-averages-mea...

We ignore the most important questions when proposing solutions. What is the best temperature to work toward for the world? How can we get to that temperature and what are the benefits we will see? Can we really control our globe's climate at all?

Ima right

Oh February 23, 2016

As a graduate student in engineering, I would have preferred a little science with my science fiction In 1800 we were in the Maunder Minimum the lowest level of sunspot activity recorded. Sun spots are a direct indication of solar output which of course determines how much energy the earth gets from the sun and the main driver of the temperature of the earth. It makes sense that the earth's temperature would have risen since then. The fact is the ecosystem of the earth is too complex for scientists to model given the current knowledge and current limitations on computing power.

aoxomoxoa

Berkeley February 23, 2016

But as a graduate student in a science-based discipline, I assume you would acknowledge that the scientists who generate these models take these factors into account. Do you assume that all these researchers somehow neglected to think about something as basic as sunspot activity cycles? One need not model the earths' entire set of interlocking ecosystems to be able to make educated projections. In fact, to refer to the "ecosystem of the earth" does make the project sound too complicated for analysis. However, I know of no scientist who think in terms of the earth as one ecosystem and attempts to model it as such.

Mary Paisley

Ithaca, NY February 23, 2016

Now the seasons are in flux and everything is changing. It makes dying harder.

Ehkzu

Palo Alto, CA February 23, 2016

A recent Pew survey of public opinion vs. scientists’ opinions shows big gaps when something conflicts with ideology. Dogmatic liberals claim that genetically modified foods are risky to eat, while nearly 90% of AAAS (American Association for the Advancement of Science) scientists say they’re safe. Dogmatic right wingers deny the fact of dangerous, man-caused climate change, while again nearly 90% of scientists (and over 99% of climate scientists) say it’s a fact that demands prompt government intervention.
So it’s not a Left vs. Right thing. The real cleavage lies between ideologues who try to force reality to conform to their ideas vs. pragmatists who let empirical reality shape their ideas, even when they don’t like the result.
But ideologues just double down when reality comes a-knocking. Hence the global warming denial entries here from Men of the Right (and they're nearly always men).
What all such comments show is how little they understand of how science arrives at its conclusions–especially how those conclusions derive from many different avenues of inquiry–of replicable observations and experiments, of logic and mathematical proofs, all converging on the same thing, such as man-caused climate change. Innumerable details are always being worked out, but this basic “inconvenient truth” is now as proven as evolution.
Which many right wing ideologues also reject, including the late Justice Scalia..

  • Flag
  • 3Recommend

Tom

Virginia February 23, 2016

"...nearly 90% of scientists (and over 99% of climate scientists) say [anthropogenic climate change is] a fact that demands prompt government intervention."

Source, please? And two points: (1) when research funding depends on the scientific view you promote, then people tend to promote that view; (2) a broad consensus, even if it were true, does not mean a theory is correct.

Where is the proof of a testable hypothesis based on the theory of anthropogenic global warming? So far all the predictions I'm aware of have failed rather badly, but maybe I've missed some.

  • Flag
  • Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Ehkzu

Palo Alto, CA February 23, 2016

Gap between public notions about science & what scientists believe:
http://www.pewinternet.org/2015/01/29/public-and-scientists-views-on-sci...

And 2 points: (1) Your point about scientists' funding is irrelevant because the vast majority of scientists in other fields agree with the climate scientists' consensus.

(2) In science, "consensus" means the ideas that are left standing after fierce gladiatorial combat that often goes on for decades, with scientists continually trying to make a name for themselves by demolishing other scientists' research. It's not a vote. It's not a democracy. It's survival of the fittest ideas.

As for the "where is the proof" stuff, in fact all the predictions have succeeded rather spectacularly. As you might know if you got your information from scientific sources instead of from the fossil fuel industry's billion dollar campaign against the science & the scientists, as detailed by Drexel U. sociologist Robert J. Brulle & others. Try www.skepticalscience.com for a start. It demolishes all the petropropaganda you're repeating.

Research funding of research that is not climate science research does not depend on the scientists seeking that funding agreeing with the climate scientists' consensus on climate science.

Yet 87% of such scientists--with none of their own financial support at stake--agree with the consensus of climate scientists.

So your first point is a crock.

axis42

Seattle, WA February 23, 2016

It does not say it was rising faster 2800 years ago, just that it is, "rising faster than at any point in 28 centuries." In other words, it's not risen this fast over that time period.

But, to answer the question, "What caused it to slow down?" The answer is in the article: Fluctuations in the global temperature: "The paper shows the ocean to be extremely sensitive to small fluctuations in the Earth’s temperature. The researchers found that when the average global temperature fell by a third of a degree Fahrenheit in the Middle Ages, for instance, the surface of the ocean dropped by about three inches in 400 years. "

And before deniers jump in claiming that the temperature of the Earth has always changed and there's no way we piddly little humans are causing the increase in average global temperature now because, "See? See? The temperature fell by a third of a degree in the MIddle Ages! It just happens." I'll say this: The average global temperature is going up now much faster than it has ever risen ever on this planet and it has been doing so since the advent of the Industrial Revolution. The emissions we are spewing are causing this round of increased temperatures and no, the system can not handle it naturally because the system is not set up to manage such sudden and drastic increases in emissions and temperatures.

You take the good with the bad, but what we can't do is stop something that the Earth has been doing naturally since time began, and that is changing.

  • Flag
  • Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Kiza Sozay

CA February 23, 2016

The NOAA has monitored tidal stations throughout the world for nearly a century. High tide, low tide, high tide, low tide. Twice a day, every day. This is actual measured data, not a computer model. From the empirical data they project forward to a 95% confidence level. The trend for most of these is a sea rise of about six inches over the next century with a confidence level of 95%. Don't take my word for it. See for yourself.
http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/sltrends_us.htm

  • 4Recommend

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 23, 2016

Many commenters – on both sides of the issue – dance around this inescapable fact: in the long run, sea level is the same everywhere. That's because water runs downhill.

I know, I know, warmer water in some places will cause the water to expand, and thus rise, to higher levels than elsewhere. I'll accept that, but the differential can only be temporary, and slight. If sea level off the coast of New York is, say, a foot higher than sea level off the coast of San Francisco, eventually the higher water off New York will find its way to the coast near San Francisco. That's how it works: Water runs downhill.

But, then, why are sea levels rising at different rates in different places? And why are sea levels falling in many places (various spots along the Oregon coast, for example, and many coastal locations in Alaska)? How can this be? The only answer I can think of is that the measurement of "sea level" is a RELATIVE measure, not an absolute measure: it's a comparison of the land level and the water level in the place where the measurement occurs. If the land is sinking, "sea level" may rise even if the water level doesn't change. Conversely, if the land is rising, "sea level" may fall even if the water level doesn't change.

  • Flag
  • 3Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Beetle

Tennessee February 23, 2016

"Sea level is the same everywhere." Well it is not! Sea level in Alaska is is decreasing at a rate of 3ft/100 years. Don't take my word for it. See for yourself.
http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/sltrends_us.htm

Richard Reiss

New York February 23, 2016

It's more interesting than that. Sea level varies widely; the seas are not 'flat,' as one would think. Local gravity (from land mass, or land ice) shifts the volumes of water around the planet. One effect will be that as land ice disappears at the poles, a slight ocean bulge will shift to mid latitudes, increasing the rate of sea level rise towards the Equator. The effects described here:
http://e360.yale.edu/feature/the_secret_of_sea_level_rise_it_will_vary_g...
http://harvardmagazine.com/2010/05/gravity-of-glacial-melt

Grant J

Carbon dating is very definitive; there is a radioactive carbon isotope that decays at a constant speed, and it is naturally occurring, so we can use those isotopes to date something that contains carbon. Climate Change has a whole lot of holes in the theory and cannot explain why the last 20 years did not in any fashion act as their models claimed it would. So, call me a moron if you wish, but personally I think comparing climate change to carbon dating is disingenuous at best and if you honestly think it's an apples to apples comparison, i encourage you to do more research on climate change.

scott allen

nebraska February 23, 2016

We have to thank our government and the EPA for the rise in CO2.
In 1975 the EPA (yes the same EPA that breached a containment dam and flooded a river with toxic waste) mandated that all vehicles be fitted with catalytic converters. With the use of these converters, which turned relative low greenhouse gases (co and hc) into super greenhouse gases CO2 and water vapor (both CO2 and water vapor are on the order of 10 times the greenhouse gases that the original CO and HC were. Thus we now have a CO2 problem.
This same EPA which mandated the converters then declares the CO2 to be a poisonous gas.
Sometimes the EPA is the problem.

  • Flag
  • 2Recommend

Carion

NM February 23, 2016

Scott you are grasping at straws. CO2 emission is not affected significantly by conversion of CO by catalytic converters in the US. Most CO2 emission comes from burning coal and from the CO2 that is produced when engines burn gasoline. The CO comes from incomplete burning. Higher efficiency engines will produce the same effect as a catalytic converter.

Tom

Virginia February 23, 2016

Well, I have a PhD and two masters degrees in math and engineering and am an active researcher. I read the papers I can and it seems to me that while there is good research (and bad) on our climate we still do not have anywhere near a good enough understanding to separate man-made contributions to climate change from natural variations, nor can we predict the climate a century into the future with any confidence at all.

I would also add that there is ample evidence of deliberate scientific corruption and biased reporting in support of the anthropogenic global warming cause, which naturally heightens my skepticism so that I need to evaluate the research myself before reaching any conclusions about it. The public tends to lose trust in science when it has been exposed as biased and corrupt.

Finally, a real scientist know that science does not provide instant answers for political purposes. It is a process that converges on tentative answers only after long periods of time and energetic debate; and skepticism is necessary to science whereas uncritical faith in received wisdom and attempting to silence debate is anti-scientific. Politically motivated advocates who exploit and influence science are detrimental to the scientific endeavor.

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 23, 2016

"Scientists say sea levels will rise 8 feet [or 6 feet, or, so say a few timid souls: 3 feet] in this century."

Many scientists made such projections – even before this century began: I remember them back to at least 1990.

How do those sea-level-projecters deal with the data reported since then? According to official measurements, sea level has risen about an inch this century here in San Francisco, less than half that much in LA.

One standard rebuttal: The rate of sea level rise won't be constant; the rise-rate will double, and then double again, and so on, throughout the century.

How frequently will this doubling occur? That depends on the projection. If you project an 8-foot rise, the rate will double more frequently than if you timidly project only a 3-foot rise. "Every 15 years" seems to be a popular choice, though I'm not sure why.

The problem with these rate-doubling assertions is that the data refutes those hypotheses too. If the rate of sea level rise will double every 15 years – or every 25 years, or whatever – shouldn't we be seeing a higher rate today than we saw in 1990? Official government measurements (NOAA, for example) show the rate has been the same throughout that period, and those same government agencies use the same rate when they project future sea level rise.

In short, while "denial" isn't appropriate, measurement IS appropriate, and actual measurements aren't supporting the disastrous hypotheses that have been presented.

  • Flag
  • 4Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Sam McGowan

Missouri City, TX February 23, 2016

Articles like this make me laugh. For one thing, there are no records for sea level going back more than about a century. For another, the claims are wildly exaggerated. I lived in Charleston, SC and currently live less than 35 miles from the Gulf of Mexico in Texas. I saw Charleston flooded once - but it was due to heavy rain, not sea rise. With certain exception, there are no towns built close enough to the sea to be affected. Tidal plains are actually marshes and the towns along them are some distance away . Miama "Beach" is actually a man-made beach. The city of Galveston is on an island and while it floods during hurrriicanes, I've never heard of flooding there in the 20 years I've lived 50 miles away. Where did these so-called "scientists" get their degrees?

andrea silverthorne

Lubec Maine February 23, 2016

If you read between the lines the crux of the story is that now scientists agree with the IPPC. Then if you dissect the story further, after they begin by talking about 2800 years ago, they then tell you the speed of the rise is really in the last fifty years. Then there is the fact they have failed to discuss where the recent rise has come from. They do not talk about the contribution of new water, and there is plenty of it where seas are rising. It comes from the oxidation of methane, the source of all water in earthand from the release of the fresh water they used in iur seas for water flooding during drilling. The source of new water is the release of methane into our seas exploding mud volcanoes, which were discovered in oil fields in the early seventies.

My view of the IPCC is that they were created to create the wrong global warming story to protect the oil and gas industry. Carbon dioxide holds no heatvthat effects us. The radiative forcing argument is based on the amount of water vapor a gas can hold. Only water vapor holds heat that can affect us. What hope do we have of escaping the current trajectory of our global fate, if tge oress will nit question a scientist like a poIitian? It is methane we must stop from rising. It makes water vapor and carbon dioxide, and it makes globs of formaldehyde, making methane the gas of extinction. Witness Elizabeth Kolbert's statement that the amount of water on earth is fixed. Not true when the amount of methane rises.

Susan Anderson

is a trusted commenter Boston February 23, 2016

ClimateCentral is a whole lot more reliable than you are. But as to "fudging" even Ted Cruz couldn't get past Admiral Titley, Navy meteorologist.
https://tamino.wordpress.com/2015/12/11/ted-cruz-just-plain-wrong/

"When Ted Cruz turned a senate hearing into his own climate denier circus, he didn’t just emphasize lower-troposphere temperature data — he deliberately ignored every other bit of climate data that exists. Way to go, Ted.

"It was mentioned that the satellite data was calibrated to radiosonde data, i.e. temperatures in the upper atmosphere measured by balloon-borne thermometers. Apparently Ted Cruz took this to mean that balloon data show global warming isn’t happening, which is wrong. Just plain wrong. He also claimed that the troposphere tempereture data (as opposed to the surface, where we live) “are the best evidence we have of whether warming is occurring,” which is wrong. Just plain wrong. That’s Ted Cruz for you."

Meanwhile, in your hermetically sealed rooms, you seem not to notice that reality is not doing your bidding.

Chicago, IL February 23, 2016

The climate is warming, The oceans are rising, they are also changing chemically in such a way that threatens life in the sea, a major food supply. They are also being over fished, threatening the collapse of fisheries worldwide. More and more land in tropical and subtropical climates is becoming desert that cannot be farmed. This is spreading rapidly. The world population cannot be adequately fed today. as we lose arable land this will become worldwide famine. Populations are already trying to move north to escape warfare and starvation. This will increase and create ever more conflict. Humanity's totally inadequate response will not even begin to reverse this catastrophe. Scientists have long warned of a "tipping point" at which the climate change will enter a self perpetuating feedback loop that no human intervention can halt. Earth might well become uninhabitable. Some believe that we may have already reached that point. I do not doubt that their fear will be borne out.

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 23, 2016

"Denial is a good way to bury this problem and go on living your life."

I agree – "denial" isn't appropriate. But measurement is. Here in San Francisco, for example, many scientists said at the turn of the century that sea levels would rise as much as 8 feet in this century (the lowest projection I can recall is 3 feet).

We're now 15 years into the century and SF sea levels have risen about an inch – less than that in Los Angeles. If someone points that out, are they "denying" climate change, "denying" science? Or are they doing what scientists do: test hypotheses by measuring what actually happens.

In the science world, nobody can just present a hypothesis and then demand that everyone accept it, regardless of what the data actually shows. A scientist can't claim all of his critics are just unwashed "science-deniers" once the data comes in.

  • Flag
  • 3Recommend

Skepticism is one thing, willful ignorance is another. If my doctor tells me my cholesterol is too high, I might get a second opinion; but I'm definitely not running out for a bacon, egg, and cheese sandwich in the interim just because I'm not 100% on the science just then.

CommonCents

Coastal Maine February 23, 2016

The Maine Geological Service has measured the slow rise of the ocean since the mid 1800's. Based on their measurements it has been 7.9” or 0.66 ft per century, this is roughly 2.2 mm. a year. A recent spike in levels has receded back to the calculated increase. Ironically, NOAA showed a rise in the ocean on the East coast, but it was the average of 4 zones. The New England zone showed a drop in the ocean levels. Sat. readings vs. ground readings.

Tom

Virginia February 23, 2016

What proper education can you tout? How do you know so much about the education of those who question the theory of anthropogenic global warming or doubt the impact is significant relative to natural climate variation?

I feel I'm well educated and I find the question of the relationship between man-made C02 emissions, specifically, and climate variations to be a thoroughly vexing one. Equally vexing is the challenge of accurately modeling our planetary climate system. There are so many confounding factors and precious little data, most of which involves proxies with highly uncertain relationships to temperature. Where do you derive such unquestionable certainty in anthropogenic global warming?

R. E.

Cold Spring, NY February 23, 2016

While this article is about the coastal impacts of the rise in ocean levels, there are so many other issues of climate change that will impact everyone, such as filthy air, inland river flooding and inadequate water supplies due to drought and extreme weather fluctuations. Last year in the Northeast we had snow cover until well into the Spring . This winter maple sugaring has already started in northern New York State. Building seawalls or population shifts from coastal cities to inland locations would be both expensive useless. Unfortunately, as other comments have pointed out, we are at the mercy of major polluters like China and other developing economies who think they should get a free pass. The least we and our European allies can do is to set an example of how these problems can be meaningfully addressed before we all have to start wearing face masks or find new sources of water. Even the rising oceans won't help the latter since they'll be so polluted that even efficient desalination technology won't be adequate for drinking water and agricultural production.

  • Flag
  • 3Recommend

Susan Anderson

is a trusted commenter Boston February 23, 2016

WRT the selection of posts that claim the effects of climate change will not be felt for several generations. (Setting aside that selections also highlight a variety of views and can be representative rather than expressing the views of the author ...)

Have you looked around? Kept up with the news? Climate change is here, and has already increased a variety of extremes in our weather. While direct attribution is difficult, it's clear that there is an element of climate change in all weather. Plenty of seacoasts (Norfolk, Florida, and my own in Boston) are already seeing the effects in bigger surges and king tides (pictures available, for example, from the Boston Harbor Associations Sea Level Rise report.

Along with the increased energy (heat) in the system (global warming) from accumulated heat-trapping greenhouse gases, there is disruption to the planetary system (climate change) which means more extremes, droughts, floods etc.

A friend's cousin's house (on the Meramec) floated downriver, and the surge there was 8 feet higher than the high that took the house, bigger than the previous record storm.

In my local weather, predictions have underestimated the amount of precipitation lately on a regular basis. My meteorologist friends tell me this is because weather prediction is based on older data.

The baseline has changed. Enough with the prevarication!

  • Flag
  • 7Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Canada February 23, 2016

Berkeley February 23, 2016

Some nations, with hundreds of millions of human residents, will experience massive losses of habitable and arable land, with considerable consequences for geopolitical stability. This actually affects people in this country, which I will emphasize, is not the entire planet. You may choose to feel that the problem is not yours and will not affect you, but you are wrong.

http://rabett.blogspot.com/2014/09/a-note-about-roger-revelle-julian.html

"A Note About Roger Revelle, Justin Lancaster and Fred Singer"

"So let's be clear:

"1. Fred Singer is the most unethical scientist, in my opinion, that I have ever met. I said so in the early 1990s, publicly, and I am still confident in the truth of this statement.

"2. The worst decision I ever made in my life was to provide a retraction of my statements in the early 1990s about Singer's nastiness. The retraction was coerced. It was required to stop the SLAPP suit brought against me by a conservative think-tank in Washington that wanted to keep Fred Singer in action.

"3. I was 95% certain that I would win my case in court. But my wife was terrified. In fact, she was terrorized by this lawsuit. We had three young children. I was a Harvard postdoc now needing to find a next academic posting. She was a graduate student at Harvard. My wife was worried about that 5% risk. She was scared we could lose our house and all our assets. .... Defending for a year took an enormous amount of my time. That is the meanness and force of a SLAPP suit.

"4. Singer distorted my words ... flat out lied in that text about my role "

Mark Bishop

Carmel, CA February 23, 2016

There are three general approaches to this problem and other problems related to climate change: mitigation (in this case, do something to at least slow sea level rise), adaptation (sea walls, move inland, etc.), or suffer. We will certainly do some blend of the three, but because I love my potential great, great grandchildren, I like putting the emphasis on the first one. Here's a partial list of what we can do.

1. Eat lower on the food chain, less meat and more fruits and vegetables.

If you can afford it…

2. Insulate our homes
3. Solar panels for electricity
4. Drive a hybrid or any high mpg car
5. LED light bulbs
6. Fly less

And because this problem is probably too big and the individual solutions too expensive to expect individual actions to make enough of a difference,

7. Encourage your elected representatives to take the problem seriously and take action by doing things like creating a carbon tax, encouraging research and development in renewable energy sources and better building design, mandating higher mpg standards, etc..

  • Flag
  • 8Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

David Chowes

New York City February 23, 2016

HAVE YOU NOTICED THAT NEWS . . .

...almost every day reports of extreme weather events on almost every night ... here in the U. S. and all around the world.

When the northeastern portions of our country experienced record cold and snow a few weeks ... many who think that climate change is a hoax ... thought that they were validated in their disbelief.

Actually climate warming predict aberrant patterns ... including extreme cold and precipitation ... as well as drought, extreme hurricanes and tornados.

The polar icecaps are melting ... which increases the level of the waters ... and each month and year ... more strange weather events.

This can also lead to movements of populations ... leading to social disruptions, conflicts and wars. Many island nations are sinking and food and portable water are disappearing. Soon we may have water futures on commodity exchanges.

But, it may be far too late to even stabilize this dangerous situation and to reverse it seems impossible.

Marshall Bern

California February 23, 2016

Responding to Rob from NOLA. The water level won't change when the ice melts, because ice raises the water level according to its weight not its volume. (Remember Archimedes running naked through the streets of Syracuse?) The melting ice that causes a rise in sea level is not the floating sea ice -- it's the ice sheets on land -- Greenland and Antarctica.

Jorgy

Harvard, MA February 23, 2016

"largely a consequence of greenhouse gases from human activity," is simply not true and leads people to think that changes in our behavior will influence changes in our climate which is preposterous. Human contribution is minuscule (3%) compared to the enormous natural forces that influence our climate that we barely understand. A study of climate change history validates this truth. Yes, we need to prepare for the effects of a changing climate, and we should invest in reducing pollution for the sake of our health.

Rob

NOLA February 23, 2016

Take a glass full of ice and fill it with water until the Ice rises above the rim of the glass. This is equivalent to the sea ice floating at the poles.

Now wait for the ice to melt and carefully clock the time it takes for the water to overflow the rim of the glass.

The result is empirical evidence that may be considered "settled science." It will also prove to you just how wrong the climate change deniers are as far as sea ice is concerned.

Jason Pontin

Cambridge, MA February 23, 2016

You don't understand the problem: it's not melting floating ice; it's ice run-off from the Greenland ice shelf, PLUS expanding sea water because of warming.

See: http://climate.nasa.gov/vital-signs/sea-level/

NYT Pick

John

New York City February 23, 2016

As yourself a question. What percentage of our species lives, currently, in coastal communities? According to the Clark bible of coastal management it seems the answer is ~44% of us live with 150 kilometers of a coast-line. Think about this, then juxtapose your thinking against this NY Times sentence:

"The findings are yet another indication that the stable climate in which human civilization has flourished for thousands of years, with a largely predictable ocean permitting the growth of great coastal cities, is coming to an end."

Basically don't go buying beach-front property to leave to your progeny. In other words we're looking at an end-game scenario where vast numbers of cities and communities will end up being abandoned. Think about that for a second...think of all the reactive permutations...what does that mean?

I can't envision all the particulars, but I can tell you what it means if we don't plan for it...and we should since we've already built it into the climate that's changing before our eyes....what it means is chaos. And the human animal is historically proven to a very unpleasant hominid when under stress. And baby...there will be stresses. Stress galore.

So it may go....

Ouch" The rate of rise is between 0.1 inches / year which means in 10 years an inch. By the way we had the same rate of rise for the last 200 years and nobody was panicing about it even though we've gotten 7-10 inches in the last 100 years.

The fact is most flooding today is a nuisance. 100 years ago millions died from flooding in some floods. Look it up. Millions dead from a flood. Now you are thinking about an inch and freaking out as if we can't deal with it.

In the last 10 years the number of people dying from all natural disasters has dropped by another 50%. In the last century we reduced the number dying from natural disasters to 2% of what it was then. By 2100 NOBODY will die from any of this. More people will die from falling out of space ships in 2100 than natural disasters.

Tom

Virginia February 23, 2016

Great. Then, given that climate models fail, without exception so far, to predict climate changes even a few years or decades hence, why should we rely on them to make predictions a century or more into the future?

What data are used to estimate the temperatures of the past? What factors effect this data? What is the uncertainty in our estimates of past temperatures and how confident are we in our statistical models for the relationship between all the factors effecting climate?

What data and analyses have proven the theory that man-made CO2 emissions are causing the climate to change in ways that cannot be explained by natural climate variations?

To answer the question in your top-level post, I'll remain skeptical of significant anthropogenic global warming until a comprehensive theory for climate change, natural and otherwise, is successfully and fully validated.

  • Flag
  • Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Jason Pontin

Cambridge, MA February 23, 2016

Never. Almost no one changes their opinion, ever. Only very confident or very scientifically educated people are capable of changing their views, and that does not describe climate change "skeptics".

  • Flag
  • Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Tom

is a trusted commenter Midwest February 23, 2016

To answer your questions, lets start with the first paragraph. Most climate models are modelling for a decade or more out in the future. Whether a climate model will predict merely a few years is not germane. Second, most of those models are only a couple of decades old or less. Time is needed to validate them. Third, any good model is revised as more data becomes available to refine a model. Fourth, all models should have confidence intervals. Some climate models do, some do not. The climate models that do have an upper and lower bound and those models are so far correctly predicting with those bounds.

Second paragraph. If you read the papers on the models, they tell you which data is used, how it was estimated and the uncertainty as well as the confidence intervals.

Third paragraph: one does not prove a theory in science. Models are created by fitting the data to a proposed prediction. Multiple regression analysis can determine whether a co variate (e.g. natural climate variations) are additive or multiplicative to the veracity of the model. So far, research has shown that natural variation cannot explain the changes in either temperature or co2 predicted by the models. Further research is showing that methane and other man made activities are more important than natural variation as well.

Last paragraph, as noted, no theory or model is either complete or comprehensive. By the time your criteria of fully validated is met, it probably will be too late.

  • Flag
  • Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Tom

is a trusted commenter Midwest February 23, 2016

add to that, the models correctly are predicting the sea level rise in Miami and other low lying areas. The problem, as noted in the article, is the actual rise is exceeding the predicted sea level rise.

It is landlocked, which means that the medieval warm period was real, although climate alarmists deny the medieval warm period. In those days, Greenland was cultivated and colonized. Vikings sailed across the North Atlantic in open ships. That warming period happened from natural causes, then was followed by a minor ice age from which we are now recovering. But according to those who are using man-man global warming to stampede us into one-world government, it never happened. They are also telling us that during the past twenty-years we were supposed to be undergoing rapid global warming, although satellite-measurement of earth temperature reveals no global warming at all. The temperature of the earth is now somewhat lower than it has been on the average over the past 3000 years. This report is more government-sponsored quack science. The major media speaking for the powers of high finance and global business are telling you lies. Don't believe them. Demand the facts. -- John Remington Graham of the Minnesota Bar (#3664X)

Beantownah

Boston MA February 23, 2016

What is frustrating about the Times' reporting on certain politically charged topics, including global warming, is its insistence on news shaping instead of news reporting. This article is an example. Instead of factually telling us that X or Y scientists are telling us Z, the reporter hysterically proclaims that The Scientists are telling us we're all doomed (again) unless we start riding bicycles and go solar. If climate change deniers are decried as embracing junk science, this is junk news. To find out which scientists are among the latest to tell us to go back to the stone age or else, one has to burrow into the article (apparently the art of writing an inverted pyramid who-what-when-where-why lead has been lost to young Times journalists). And even after such burrowing it is unclear who exactly is saying what here, and compared to who else. The reader is left discomfited and unenlightened, but at least can look forward to enjoying the Sports and Styles section (please don't ruin those for us, Times).

  • Flag
  • Recommend

Mac

chicago, IL February 23, 2016

Measuring sea level is a tricky thing. A tide gauge will give a sort of measure of sea level, but, only a relative one. If, as is the case with the Eastern coast of the United States, the land mass is sinking, the sinking while appear to be a rise in relative sea level. By contrast, the Pacific Northwest land mass is generally rising at the coast.

So, while there may be a rise in the absolute level of the oceans due to global warming, it is misleading to place the blame on global warming for increase risk of the flooding along the Eastern coast of the US, which is actually predominately caused by the sinking of the land mass.

  • Flag
  • 2Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

LI'er

NY February 23, 2016

A friend of mine has a house on a coastal barrier in LI. On leaving her house after dinner one evening, my daughter and I turned left out of her driveway, heading for the bridge that would take us over the bay. It had rained, so we didn't think much of driving through the first big puddle, but shortly we realized we were actually driving through open bay water that had, as the tide came in, over-washed the entire road. It was not a spring tide or a king tide, or any other kind of extraordinary tide. It was a stark example of rising sea level. We found our way back to the other end of the road by reversing away from the bay, and hugging the sand dunes on the ocean side till we reached the road again, and took another bridge after driving through another, shallower over wash. Yes, people, we are sinking! I have seen it with my own eyes.

Bill O'Keefe

New Kent Virginia February 23, 2016

According to Professor Carl Wunsch of MIT and one of the world's leading oceanographers, reconstructing sea levels that far back is a fiction. There are too many unknowns and too many assumptions that have to be made. He also has pointed out that sea levels have been rising for 16,000 years since the end of the last ice age and will continue to rise until the next one.
May be the apocalyptic can build a model that predicts one in our lifetime.

All you have to do is pay attention to the weather, every week there's another monster record setting storm. At Glacier National Park there used to be 100's of glaciers, now there's like 26 left. It's everywhere. And you add that to all other things like coral reefs dying, the Japanese nuke accident, Katrina ....

So we can either just go on with business as usual because we are all through anyway, or we can try to slow it down. I'll tell you one thing I would do, and it may sound trivial or dumb; but I would start a huge desalination project up and down the West Coast, the Gulf and parts of the East. Draw water out of the oceans, make it fresh and use it for all the drought areas, irrigation, fighting fires, fracking, whatever. Build new pipelines that go as far as the mid-west. Maybe we can actually transfer enough to actually make a difference as far as sea level rise, and be putting it to good use.

This city sits at the center of a land locked country it is a 1st that we start sweating, at mid day, where we just sat hardly moving physically.Also, when the coastal people r forced inland more congestion, possible deforestation 4 buildings and significant disruption 2 the ecology may follow.Add to that the still not fully grasped possible change* in the whole configuration of the universe and beyond and intervening in is beyond the capacity of humans, even if all wars ended, nature could still do all of us in.At least, if through measures like minimizing or eliminating green house emissions, extensive reforestation,assisting developing economies using alternatives other than getting hooked 2 various CO2 releasing paths could result in sufficient mitigation outcome.Einstein conjectured a statement that got proved by a team of Mathematical Physicists 100 yrs later.If humans devote enough of their brain and resources * may b grasped.TMD,AAU+Rutg+SUNYA Math Alum

XYZ123

California February 23, 2016

I'm was curious about the pro/con ratio of commenters that deny the very existence of global warming/climate change to those who accept and think it is urgent to deal with. But the NYT does not make such research easy. The comment view-add window is restrictive and awkward. There's no search function, and no way to show all comments and replies together.

As for sea level rises and other devastating climate change I tend to prefer to see it through the eyes of polar bears, whales, and other wild life. Their disruptive and unguided migration patterns, survival rates, and suitability of new habitat can tell the lay people who do not want to hear about science that a serious trend is taking place in nature, and that being oblivious to it will not make it go away. In that prism of caring about defenseless creatures it is very bleak and heartbreaking.

You know, in the Southern Indian city of Kumbhakonam "Mahamaham" is being celebrated. It represents the the convergence of all the seven sacred rivers of the Indian subcontinent with the start of Kali Yuga. This is due to sea levels rising to the point where all rivers become one and go under the ocean water. People immerse themselves in a tank that is supposed to carry all the seven sacred rivers and also look up at the sky with the five planets aligned across the sky (which happens once in ten or twelve years) that also, according to Hindu cosmology, sometimes (once in a few hundred years) signals a worm hole (that appears once in few hundred years) to go into a more evolved planet, maybe the most evolved in our universe, the Brahma Loka (also known as Satya Loka).

These Rishis, spiritually evolved beings, knew in their foresight, through intuition and through scientific observations and forecasting, that sea levels will rise due to human greed and stupidity as well as due to some natural changes in climate patterns that would lead to flooding and convergence of all rivers as oceans flood coastal cities and submerge land.

Start working for betterment of humanity, justice for all, fairness for all, protection of Mother Earth, greater self awareness and better self development...with planet health and growth beyond tribalism.

Start by immersing yourself in your water with respect, joy and a sense of global responsibility or duty.

Patrice Ayme

Hautes Alpes February 23, 2016

The situation is actually cataclysmic. The United Nations’ IPCC did not include in its computations the possible melting of the ice shields of Greenland and Antarctica. It was viewed as impossible, for a few millennia; no plausible mechanism was held to be plausible to melt said ice shields. How naïve.

My reasoning is the exact opposite: first an obvious mechanism for ice shield melting exists: the ice shields can be up to 4 kilometers thick. They press down on the continental crust so much, that a lot of Greenland and Antarctica is well below sea level. Not by just a few hundred feet, but outright, kilometers. Those areas are protected by rock thresholds on the margins of the ice shields (where the crust goes back up, because where the ice ends, there is no more weight pressing down on the continent). Right now, warm water, denser at 4C, eats at the “grounding lines” where the ice of the shields touches the rock. When past the threshold, warm water drops down on the other side, deeper than the Grand Canyon, and can melt a Texas sized ice shield ice shield in a few decades, as will be found all too soon.

Three scientific papers published in the last two months support this point of view. One observed the collapse of a colossal glacier in northwest Greenland, eaten by a sea current at one degree C. Two others observed the past, and that Antarctica was unstable at 500 ppm CO2. We are right now at more than 450 ppm in EQUIVALENT CO2, and will be at 500 ppm within ten years.

  • Flag
  • 26Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Nancy

Vancouver February 23, 2016

And once the Antarctic ice starts to melt and shrink, ocean currents all over the world will be disrupted.

Here is a fascinating video of the inter-connectedness of almost everything having to do with the Antarctic ice, including the Sahara and the Amazon rainforest.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=esMX5NIsHdk

Hoser

Sonora, CA February 23, 2016

And of course they don't tell you it was warmer than today in the Medieval Warm Period - despite all our evil "carbon" releases that were not in the air 700 years ago. And they don't tell you it was even warmer during the Roman Warming, almost 2000 years ago. But it was warmer still during the Minoan Warm Period about 3500 years ago. You see, since the end of the last glaciation 10000 years ago, we reached the Holocene optimum with sea level estimated at about 6 feet higher than today. All this happened with atmospheric CO2 at about 280 ppmv. What that tells you is we are on a bumpy temperature ride down to the next glaciation. So enjoy the warm times while you can. In about 20,000 there will be ice covered areas once again that will eventually have ice two miles thick. But for now, the excess CO2 is greening the Earth, even the edges of the deserts. More CO2 helps plants resist droughts. But go ahead and fall for the pseudoscience and destroy this fascist economy. It certainly isn't Capitalism any more. The goal is to get you to give up on freedom and be made "safe". From what? A scary story. It's a bunch of hot air. And you know Al Gore is laughing at how gullible you are. And you want to be just like your friends, the other "caring" people going on their hopefully only economic suicide mission? Have fun with that. Just remember, 70 million people died as a result of Mao's Cultural Revolution. And a lot of them were devout commies who thought they were on his side.

CastleMan

Colorado February 23, 2016

It will not be thousands of years before sea level rise severely affects our civilization.

By the end of this century every city on the U.S. east coast will have to face the cost and tumult that comes with an abandonment of buildings and structures within the zone affected.

The rising seas will follow rising temperatures. The average air temperature in many areas of the U.S. will be, if we don't change our energy ways very soon, as much as 8-10 degrees Fahrenheit higher than it is now. Say goodbye to the Midwest bread basket. Say hello to tropical disease in the heartland.

The planet will be a biological wasteland, as the majority of species of animals and plants are exterminated from the Earth by a warmer atmosphere and an acidified ocean.

Wars will be far more common as nations, or tribes, fight for water and agricultural land, and to fend off a growing surge of refugees everywhere, while famine stalks the globe.

We must act and the time to do it is now. All government-provided incentives for fossil fuel production must end. A price on carbon dioxide emissions must be put in place. Those are the starting steps. If we, as a society, decline to take them, we are guaranteeing the chaotic, destructive, even apocalyptic future climate change will bring.

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 23, 2016

My local paper, the San Francisco Chronicle, reported last week that the steep gasoline tax increases over the past decade or so have worked. Drivers of gas guzzlers apparently have become so sick of paying those high gasoline taxes that they've either cut back on their driving or switched to more fuel-efficient cars.

That's a good thing, right? That was the whole point of the gas tax hike, wasn't it?

Apparently not.

According to the Chronicle, government officials have become dismayed at the sharp drop in gas tax revenues. What to do? Simple, some would-be problem-solvers say. Just start basing transportation taxes on mileage traveled rather than gasoline used.

If CA switches from a "gas tax" to a "mileage tax," someone driving a Prius will pay the same tax as someone driving a Hummer. But that's only fair, the problem-solvers insist: according to the Chronicle article, owners of gas guzzlers have been complaining that they pay more than their fair share of transportation taxes – Hummer drivers have been subsidizing Prius drivers, in other words.

Does this idea make sense? It depends on what you're trying to accomplish. If you're trying to raise tax revenues – which, again, have declined sharply since CA drivers have done exactly what they were expected to do: use less gas – a mileage-base tax makes great sense. But what if your objective is to induce drivers to use more fuel-efficient cars – remember that? In that case – well, not so much.

I am not making this up.

  • Flag
  • 8Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

David Taylor

norcal February 23, 2016

It's important to note that even Hummers are too light to cause any measurable damage to roads. In terms of wear and tear, passenger vehicles are all pretty much the same in their impact. It's large trucks that do all the damage, but if you can convince the legislature to tax trucks sufficiently to pay for all road maintenance, I will believe it when I see it.

For reference, road damage goes with the 4th power of the weight. So going from Prius to Hummer causes 16x the damage, going from hummer to semi is 1000x the damage.

  • Flag
  • 5Recommend

ebmem

Memphis, TN February 23, 2016

Who should pay for road maintenance? A high gas tax is intended to reduce fuel consumption so it did its job. So now another funding choice is needed to pay for roads.

The taxes on cigarettes have caused a reduction in smoking and a subsequent reduction in tax collections.

The carbon tax Obama has proposed, or any other carbon tax, will result in diminishing tax collections over time. So it is imperative that the taxes not be spent on anything other than reduction of the federal debt. That way when carbon dioxide production has been completely eliminated, at least there will be somewhat of a reduction in the amount of interest the taxpayers will have to chip in for interest payments.

if you impose a tax to discourage a behavior, you cannot use revenue collected for anything that is essential.

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 23, 2016

I've had similar experiences, as, I'm sure, many drivers have. Trucks (and other heavy vehicles) do much more damage to roads and bridges than do smaller cars (or motorcycles). That's why those heavier vehicles pay higher taxes, at least here in CA -- higher annual registration fees, higher gas tax. That's the way it should be, and that's the way it is – even here in CA, despite the idea discussed in this article, which would impose the same tax on a Prius driver as on a Hummer driver.

  • Flag
  • Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 23, 2016

"if you impose a tax to discourage a behavior, you cannot use revenue collected for anything that is essential."

Interesting conclusion – hard to believe that's what you really intended. If you "cannot use revenue collected for anything that is essential," doesn't that imply you can only use that revenue for something that is NOT essential? And doesn't that, in turn, suggest that maybe you shouldn't be collecting that tax in the first place?

Other taxing jurisdictions haven't come up with this idea (at least not to my knowledge). They pay for road maintenance in one of two ways: (1) out of general revenues; or (2) out of various forms of user fees – more gas tax revenues (i.e. have the Hummer drivers continue to subsidize the Prius drivers), higher registration fees for cars with bigger engines, or for trucks, etc., on the ground that heavy vehicles do more damage to the roads.

The point of the latter methods is that the taxing jurisdiction should solve its revenue problem WITHOUT ceasing to reward the Prius drivers, who, after all, have done exactly what the government has asked them to do: use less gas.

  • Flag
  • Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 23, 2016

Most taxing jurisdictions agree with you. In CA, for example, it costs considerably more each year to renew the registration of a Hummer than of a Prius, and gas taxes remain in effect despite the idea discussed in this article.

  • Flag
  • 11Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Jay

Texas February 23, 2016

Sorry Roy but it has everything to do with it....because these are real statistical differences in scale. And this is the ground we live on.... We live in a period geologists and anthropologists call the Holocene. Warming of Earth and glacial retreat began about 14,000 years ago (12,000 BC). The warming was shortly interrupted by a sudden cooling at about 10,000 - 8500 BC known as the Younger-Dryas. The warming resumed by 8500 BC. The younger-dryas event is significant because it shows that even during an otherwise tranquil period (the current interstatal), rapid climate shifts can still occur. But between 5000 to 3000 BC average global temperatures reached their maximum level during the Holocene and were 1 to 2 degrees Celsius warmer than they are today. Climatologists call this period either the Climatic Optimum or the Holocene Optimum. Which means we haven't RETURNED to the Optimum yet....and back then that optimum was only minimally influenced by humans.

  • Flag
  • 3Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

b fagan

Chicago February 23, 2016

Jay, the Earth has existed for over 4.5 billion years. The Gregorian calendar has only been in use since 1582 - by your logic, we can't possibly know what day it is.

As Roy points out, greenhouse gas is going to act like greenhouse gas. You could build a brand-new replica Earth, and if you build it like the one we have today, and put it just as far from the sun as we are, and increase the levels of greenhouse gases like we are, the surface temperature will rise.

Luomaike

New Jersey February 23, 2016

Ok, so you can’t expect Americans to believe scientists. How about the oil companies themselves? Even as they were embarking on a policy of disinformation to discredit climate change science in 1980’s and 1990’s, they were already starting to prepare for the effects of climate change on their own industry.

“From the North Sea to the Canadian Arctic, the companies were raising the decks of offshore platforms, protecting pipelines from increasing coastal erosion, and designing helipads, pipelines and roads in a warming and buckling Arctic.” As only one example, “Shell Oil announced in 1989 that it was raising its “Troll” North Sea natural gas platform a meter or two in anticipation of climbing sea levels caused by climate change.” (http://graphics.latimes.com/oil-operations/)

In addition, “Exxon used its knowledge of climate change to plan its own future. The company, for instance, leased large tracts of the Arctic for oil exploration, territory where…potential global warming can only help lower exploration and development costs.” (http://graphics.latimes.com/exxon-arctic/)

Sounds like the industry that is most in the middle of the link between burning fossil fuels and climate change hasn’t wasted any time planning for its future. Maybe it’s time the rest of us got on board?

  • Flag
  • 10Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 22, 2016

Know what's most amusing?

Many scientists project that sea levels will rise 8 feet in California this century, but they've risen one inch so far, through 2015. Another reader responded that I was mistaken about the numbers – it must be 8 inches, not 8 feet.

Nope. No mistake. Eight feet is what these scientists say, not 8 inches. When I read such a response, I wonder: Did this projection of an 8-foot rise also strike that reader as shoot-from-the-hip speculation –as not being "science" at all? It tend to think it did. Though I tried to be vague in earlier comments (lest the Times not publish my comment), my point was that an 8-foot rise is pure speculation – and speculation that has little or no basis in fact when one considers that 15 of those 100 years have already passed and sea level has risen only 1 inch so far.

What's ironic is that those who insist we accept "science" don't accept science themselves.

The scientific method involves more than just presenting hypotheses and demanding that everyone accept them as proven fact. Science involves measurement too. You hypothesize, and then you measure. If feasible, you measure the results of experiments. If experiments aren't feasible, you just measure. Either way, if the measurements don't support your hypothesis -- for example, when you hypothesize that sea levels will rise 8 feet in 100 years but they've only risen 1 inch during the first 15 years of that century – you revise your hypothesis.

That's how science works.
