willow

Las Vegas, NV February 23, 2016

You are assuming that the rate of increase is constant.
But if the rate of increase doubles every 15 years, in the first 15 years the rise is 1 inch, the next 15 years the rise is 2 inches, by the last 15 years in a century the rise will be 64 inches or 5 ft. 4 inches. Add the totals for each set of 15 years and you get 127 inches or over 10 feet.

Climate change is not linear and it is not reversible. Also there is a time lag in its effects. Small observable changes now mean very big changes in the future if we continue to emit emissions at the current rate.

  • Flag
  • 10Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 23, 2016

Standard response:

"You are assuming that the rate of increase is constant.
But if the rate of increase doubles every 15 years...."

Yes, and if the rate of increase quadruples every 15 minutes, sea level will rise ever more. But guess what? YOUR assumption that the rate of sea level rise will double (and then double again, and so on) is just another assumption not supported by measured facts. Sea level rise has been measured pretty much everywhere for at least 150 years. Look at the NOAA data: no detectable rise in the rate in a very long time. In Los Angeles, for example, the average reported annual rise is .88 millimeters. That hasn't changed in a very long time, and the NOAA uses that number in its projections. You don't -- that I get. But you start from your conclusion and work backward to your assumptions. That isn't how science works.

CityBumpkin

Earth February 23, 2016

The answer is they could, and there is plenty of information freely available to everyone explaining why and how. The short version is there is indeed natural climate change over time. However, human beings, by injecting large amounts of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere into a short amount of time, is accelerating the process.

All instances of rapid climate change throughout the geological record have been bad news for existing lifeforms. Slow changes give existing life time to adapt. Rapid changes do not. That's why they tend to cause mass extinctions. Nature gives us enough to worry about without us making things worse for ourselves.

Texan from Canada

Austin, TX February 22, 2016

The belief that man’s contribution to CO2 has altered the world’s weather to any significant degree is based upon, at most, 150 years of recorded meteorological records of any worth, in a post glacial warming period of some 30,000 years.

Any statistician worth his salt will tell you that a single segment of a trend that has been in effect at least 100 times longer is useless as a predictor. From other clues – the migration of plant species, the history written in the ice caps, even the rudimentary meteorological records of the recent past – we know there were many anomalies in the current warming cycle much greater than that we are experiencing now.

Eliminate all man-made carbon emissions and the Earth will continue to warm, at just about the same rate, with even more severe anomalies. Those are natural events, part of the process.

Yes, coastal areas will flood. Major cities will be inundated. The oceans’ advance has happened many times in Earth’s geological history. Just consider the sedimentary evidence found hundreds of miles inland from today’s shorelines. The process is inexorable and would continue, at an only minutely slower rate, even if mankind ceased to exist.

Don’t disrupt the world’s economy in an attempt to stop it. That per force cannot succeed and, if carried to the extremes proponents demand, will have devastating effects.

The idea that a change in our behavior could stop the process is ludicrous on its face. Canute, hold back the tide!

Brian Sussman

New Rochelle, NY February 22, 2016

Ultimately, there are two choices: Either greatly reduce use of carbon-based fuels (while avoiding expansion of harmful nuclear fuel); or abandon our coastal cities including much of NYC, much of Long Island, much of Florida, etc., and move our cities to higher land.

It would be less destructive and financially less expensive to reduce use of carbon-based fuels but to not replace them with dangerous nuclear reactors, than to move our cities to our higher ground.

Additional to using solar, wind, rivers and tides to generate electricity, what is really needed is massive use of functional superconductors and supermagnets, which would provide much more efficient use of electricity and transportation, as well as permitting electrical generation to occur far away from major population centers.

Solar panels don't make much sense in cloudy NY, but would be very useful in deserts. Our currently highly inefficient use of electrical generation, transmission and usage, if replaced with superconductivity and supermagnetism, would provide much more energy with less pollution, less inefficiency and far cheaper.

Therefore, the federal government should invest much money in perfecting inexpensive superconductivity and supermagnetism.

Brian Sussman

New Rochelle, NY February 23, 2016

The USA, Europe and China have relatively low reproduction rates.

High reproduction occurs in India, elsewhere in Asia, and in Africa and South America (basically in low income areas where lifespans are lower and infant mortality higher).

The problem with your solution, is there is no way in a democracy, to force contraception or abortion on people. China has done so, hence its low birthrate, but it is a dictatorship in a society where individual freedoms are not traditional nor permissible under its repressive government.

I do believe that people should be free to use contraception and abortion, and that our government should pay for such family planning.

However, limiting population growth will in itself do nothing to prevent global warming, although it would have many beneficial affects.

Ironically, global warming will inhibit population growth for a number of reasons including food shortages, increased major wars world-wide, and disruption of civilization. Global warming might well lead to a new 'dark age' in western civilization, and perhaps all advanced civilizations.

Jim in Tucson

Tucson February 22, 2016

A recent study of driving habits in Westwood Village, home of UCLA, found that local drivers burn 47,000 gallons of gasoline, and produce 730 tons of CO2 per year--just cruising for parking spaces around campus. American drivers add 1.5 billions tons per year of CO2 to the atmosphere.

The effects of carbon dioxide on heat absorption were shown 150 years ago by a Swedish scientist, Svanate Arrhenius, one of the first winners of a Noble Prize. The formula he developed to predict the heat rise caused by CO2 accumulation in the atmosphere has proved to be extremely accurate for more than a century.

The fact is, the only people on this planet who consistently question the existence of climate change are American conservatives. Can anyone imagine that the millions of petro-dollars the Koch brothers contribute to the Republican Party could have something to do with that?

Maybe now that their lawns are being poisoned by salt water from rising tides, some of the doubters might take a second look at the possibility.

I doubt we can change the progress now, for even if we took steps (which we should) we would still have continued effects of carbon emissions that started in the late 18th century. The New Yorker claims that there's no hope for any remedy, but there are dikes and pumps. It becomes a matter of infrastructure--massive infrastructure--such as The Netherlands have known for centuries. I admit that I haven't researched this issue. I might though, if I ever find a supporter who has made an honest attempt at proving the "human driven global warming" hypothesis false, and upon sober reflection, found that the hypothesis was indeed true.

As an engineer, I know full well that scientists are fallible just like everyone else. All scientific models are wrong, but some are useful ;)

Charles

Tecumseh, Michigan February 23, 2016

@ Tom B.: So is the problem that the seas are rising or that too many people are living close to the coastline? What would be the ideal rate of sea rise? Do you really think that "climate scientists" can design a system to modulate sea rise to ideal rate? The most deceptive aspect of the entire climate change "crisis" is that advocates consistently cite some statistic that even if true is meaningless when considered across eons. If 2015 was indeed the warmest "on record" that means that it was the warmest year since about 1880, and all that means is that the Earth has been getting warmer during the past 135 years. Has the earth ever gotten warmer during a 135 year period in the past? Countless times.

Ray

Texas February 22, 2016

There are millions and millions of people in China and India who want more power, for their appliances and vehicles, easily erasing any gains made in Europe and the USA. Besides, no one is going to inconvenience themselves for a solution that doesn't have a defined result. We'll just have to rely on human innovation, to come up with an alternative power source in the future.

Engines can run without fuel. A Ford engine has demonstrated it can be done. Two more engines are being converted. Millions can be readily manufactured worldwide. See aesopinstitute.org for more information.

Our freedom and "convenience" includes the convenience of dumping waste carbon into the atmosphere that our descendants will have the responsibility of dealing with, it's certainly not our responsibility. We'll leave it to them to "innovate". We'll leave it to them to "find alternative power sources".
Without paying for the costs of dumping all that carbon we are stealing from the world of our children to fund the "convenience" of our present lives. Spare me the whining that China and India obviates our responsibility to do anything.
To quote Khaled Hosseini, "There is only one sin. And that is theft...there is no act more wretched than stealing." We are wretched thieves.

John Warnock

Thelma KY February 23, 2016

I recycle what I can, eat less red meat, replace old bulbs with LEDs, drive fuel efficient vehicles. I do not feel inconvenienced in the least and enjoy paying less for fuel and electricity. Those are some of the things the article mentions that we can each do without breaking stride. It may not seem to mean much individually but collectively can help make a big difference. During the winter months I open the blinds on the east side of my house and let the morning sun shine through. It feels great and delays the furnace kicking on while I get to bask in the free warmth. Little things do make a difference and if people develop a positive attitude about the matter it would go a long way to changing the politics of global warming in the process.

Patrick

Move out of a flood zone before you lose it all.

  • Flag
  • 9Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 22, 2016

I've lived in San Francisco a little over 40 years now. A few months back, I wondered how much sea level has risen since I got here. According to official reports, it's risen a couple of inches (though many climate scientists say it will rise 8 feet during this century). But I hadn't noticed any rise along the shore, so I visited some of the places I used to spend a lot of time at when I first moved here.

Answer: You can't tell. Tides affect water levels in the SF Bay a great deal. When I walked around the Marina Green, for example, the water level was very low, but I realized the tide was out.

I can't notice any change in the sea level when I walk along the ocean beaches, compared to 40 years ago, but, again, it's hard to tell. The ocean beaches are affected by tides too (albeit not as much as the SF Bay).

All in all, we're pretty lucky out here on the West Coast, at least when it comes to sea level rise. Official government reports show sea levels rise more quickly along the East Coast and South Coast (especially Louisiana) than along the West Coast. We even have some coastal areas in Oregon, not far north of here, where sea levels are falling, and that's happening even more so along the south coast of Alaska.

I used to think that sea level must rise the same everywhere, but I've learned that that's not so. Good thing for us out here -- not so good for you East Coasters (not to mention Louisiana).

  • Flag
  • 6Recommend

schan4

Boston, MA February 22, 2016

The author is hypocritical, he directly points the finger on green house emissions on burning of fossil fuels yet he fails to mention the elephant in the room-the billions of farm animals. The major contributor to green house gas is the billions of farm animals we raise and slaughter to satisfy our cravings.

Raising farm animals require a lot of energy- this includes transportation of food and the its end product, water resources. The methane produced by many of the farm animals is also anothe contributor to green house gases.

Another major contributor to green house gases is humans. There is simply too much of us at this point. Eventually when the time comes, we will have to face a difficult choice, lower the farm animal population, wild animal population or human population.

Nick

USA February 22, 2016

Your response is precisely my problem - the deception taking place in academia. While I commend your brother on achieving his PhD, I do not appreciate the fear mongering originating in his field of study. I would point to a white paper titled 'Mass Gains of the Antarctic Ice Sheet Exceed Losses' by Dr. H. Jay Zwally et al. that inconveniently exposes falsehoods such as the ones discussed in this article. This nonsense is nothing more than a political ploy responsible for spending over a billion dollars of taxpayer money per day on a global scale, and sadly there is no answer to explain the "pause" in warming over the last 18 years. Don't get me wrong. I do not want to see Battery Park permanently under water, or anyone who lives along the coastline for that matter. All I'm saying is there is valid data available disproving all the claims made my climate alarmist. On a side note, nothing would make me happier than clean burning natural gas becoming the number one energy source in the world.

Quick bio on Dr. Zwally: Dr. H. Jay Zwally is Chief Cryospheric Scientist at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center and Project Scientist for the Ice Cloud and Land Elevation Satellite (ICESat). His recent research includes leading comprehensive analysis of the mass balance of the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets and ice shelves, discovery of the melt-acceleration effect on the flow of the Greenland ice sheet, and comprehensive mapping of sea ice freeboard and thickness.

Gert

New York February 22, 2016

@Nick: You seem to think that Zwally's results mean that the sea level situation is not as bad as most scientists believe. Yet that conclusion doesn't follow from his results: "The good news is that Antarctica is not currently contributing to sea level rise, but is taking 0.23 millimeters per year away. But this is also bad news. If the 0.27 millimeters per year of sea level rise attributed to Antarctica in the IPCC report is not really coming from Antarctica, there must be some other contribution to sea level rise that is not accounted for." So you see, sea levels still seem to be rising as much as the IPCC says. And whom did that quotation come from, you might wonder? Dr. Zwally himself!

Know It All

Brooklyn, NY February 22, 2016

Call me a climate realist in drawing attention to two startling statements from this alarmist article:

“The oceans are rising faster than at any point in the last 28 centuries, . . .”

The earth is 4.5 billion years old. How is 2800 years representative of anything?! It’s only relevant if you want to attribute variability in the earth’s climate solely to man made causes.

“Scientists already knew that the sea level rose drastically at the end of the last ice age, by almost 400 feet, causing shorelines to retreat by up to 100 miles in places.”

The last ice age ended over 12,000 years ago after large areas of the earth were covered in glaciers for nearly 1.8 million years! So, of course when the glaciers retreated, that meant massive rises in sea levels.

Perhaps, given the less than 3000 years of civilized man, there is more at work here than what we’ve been doing as a species?! And if that is the case, all of our climate change efforts will be for absolutely naught.

What we should be doing is implementing long-term changes like:
> retreating inland,
> managing work, home and crops to handle the highs and lows of variable temperatures and weather, and
> drastically decreasing the footprint of man on the planet – mainly by reducing our population from over 6 billion to less than 1 billion.

We need to get over ourselves in thinking we can manage the planet. We need to adapt or die – preferably the latter and the few survivors can pick up the pieces.

  • Flag
  • 4Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

  • Flag
  • 3Recommend

Frank Baudino

Aptos, CA February 22, 2016

Agreed. We should remember (?) that, during the Cretaceous, the Western interior Seaway covered much of North America. It was 1000 km wide, stretching from the Rockies to the Appalachians and was 760 m deep. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Interior_Seaway

It makes sense to: conserve, reduce our use of carbon-based fuels, develop alternative sources of energy. But, as the above writer points out, global warming caused the glaciers to start melting 12,000 years ago--long before industrialization. It's doubtful that global warming can be reversed--at least until the next ice age. For most of the earth's history, there was no permanent ice. Seasonal ice, yes--but no permanent ice.

The best thing for us to do is learn to adapt.

michjas

Phoenix February 22, 2016

It's pretty much an epidemic that folks assume the worst when it comes to climate change, even if the science doesn't support them. One of the hardest things to predict is future extreme weather. There is little doubt that temperatures will become warmer, because that's what global warming is all about. As for extreme weather, we are already experiencing that. Will warmer temperatures increase the extremes? According to the EPA, it is somewhat likely but scientific models are not presently able to confirm this complex issue. It irritates me that folks who pretend to be champions of science are so comfortable making stuff up.

BBBear

Green Bay February 22, 2016

Few are aware that global warming has been buffered by "global dimming" of the sun's solar energy. Ironically, the 911 attack allowed climate researchers to study the effect of jet contrail pollution on solar incidence. Their findings are both shocking and important (http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/sun/ ). The "Dimming the Sun" documentary is available at PBS and likely available at your local library.

BBBear

Green Bay February 22, 2016

Wrong Robert! Take your own advice and do the reading/watching. The research, conducted largely by a UW-Madison scientist, shows that contrails have been reflecting solar energy, thus keeping the Troposphere cooler. Further, they warn that we have to be careful about how quickly we clean the Troposphere of pollution, lest we allow serious, quick heat up of the Troposphere.

Rik Myslewski

San Francisco February 22, 2016

I've noticed that a number of commenters one this article deny climate change and decry those who accept it as fool, tools, world-government fascists, or worse.

Hmmm ...

It’s time to stop responding to climate-change deniers when they post on forums such as this one.

I've been debating climate-science deniers for years — online, in person, in my writings both published and private — and I've now come to the conclusion that it's a fool’s errand. No amount of fact-based reasoning sways them, no amount of well-vetted data convinces them, no refutation of even the most illogical of their assertions — the global conspiracy of greedy grant-driven hoaxers, for example — leads them any closer to the realization that they are quite provably incorrect. And, needless to say, merely swapping insults — sadly, a more and more common time-waster — is pointless.

My suggestion: ignore them. Read what they have to say, discover if any of their arguments are of value to your understanding of climate science and policy, and if they aren’t — which, let’s be honest, is usually the case — simply don't respond. It's pointless to do so, and it only encourages them by giving their "arguments" the honor of refutation and more credence than they deserve.

It's time to simply say, "You're wrong" (in our heads, not in print) and move on, using our energies for more important things, such as influencing national policy on climate-change mitigation and adaptation.

Only those afraid of what challenging the theory will result in, fear that! Ask Stephen Hawkings, no one challenges and changes his theories more often. It's called science!

CityBumpkin

Earth February 23, 2016

First, we are not "swimming in it." The production surplus is short term because several global players had changed their production strategies and China has suffered an economic slowdown. Second, we have not run out of oil in no sall part because oil consumption habits have changed. Although new players like China and India have increased consumption, Western countries like the US have lowered consumption.

Projection from 1994 had the US consuming 23 million barrels per day by 2012. The actual number was about 18.5 million barrels. I suspect you were among those who ridiculed the policies to reduce oil consumption, and now you are using the progress made by those same policies to justify your nonsensical argument.

Martin Pollard

So what if we have to rebuild some bridges and roads or lose some oceanfront property. We are not talking about a tidal wave here. We've got a hundred years to plan and build. But most importantly, adapting with infrastructure, in proximity to the effects, is much more politically feasible than trying to convince conservatives or the scientifically illiterate to buy into restricting growth based on a weather forecast (as they see it).

I'm not against investing in a greener more sustainable lifestyle but arguing science against the deniers and resistors is not and will not work. It's time to get practical.

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 22, 2016

No doubt you're right, but some of our descendants will have it easier than others. Out here on the West Coast, for example, sea level rises much more slowly than it does on the East Coast (the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration – NOAA – publishes some useful figures). In Louisiana, sea levels are rising even faster than on the East Coast, according to NOAA figures.

Some areas are lucky, though. Just a bit north of where I live (San Francisco), there are several coastal spots in Oregon where sea levels are actually falling, and that's true even more so along the south coast of Alaska.

Here in SF, it's not too bad. According to NOAA, sea level has risen only an inch since 2000. (Many scientists have predicted an 8-foot rise here during this century, so it looks like we can expect a sudden dramatic rise for the rest of the century.) LA is even luckier than SF. According to the NOAA, sea level has been rising only about .88 millimeters a year there (about an inch every thirty years).

I used to assume sea level would rise the same everywhere, but I guess not. I wonder whether they take account of land levels too, not just water levels.

These scientists are backcasting to mine the data and using the changes they found to forecast the rate of rise. This isn't about "panic and hysteria" but rather about being able to take steps to slow the rate and for people to prepare. Myopia is easy, taking action is hard.

Fallopia

Tuba February 22, 2016

Population reduction, yes; but in the meantime if more—at least half—of the world's population would adopt a vegan diet, this would reduce the current overpopulation of cattle and other agricultural land animals we have. Livestock emissions account for as much as 51% of the greenhouse gases—not 18% as previously reported:

http://advocacy.britannica.com/blog/advocacy/2009/10/livestock-emissions...

Of course it isn't likely that the number of vegans will increase much beyond what it is now—about 3%, last I looked—but because animal agriculture takes such a huge toll on the environment, including the atmosphere, it would be wise to adopt a lifestyle that's less destructive to the planet. (And newsflash: leather isn't a "byproduct" of the meat industry; there's a whole leather industry that would continue slaughtering animals even if everyone stopped eating meat.)

http://www.onegreenplanet.org/animalsandnature/leather-is-more-than-a-by...

Since most humans have procreated or plan on procreating, we can expect the world's population to exceed 9 billion within a few years. It's probably a good idea not to allow everyone who wants to drive—even a Prius—to drive just because they want to. Public transportation will be sufficient for a congested population.

  • Flag

AJ

Michigan February 22, 2016

One of the biggest challenges to addressing climate change, besides the enormous monied interests opposing it, is that we humans have a hard time conceptualizing long-term consequences. Immediate dangers like natural disasters and terrorism capture the public consciousness far more effectively. Climate change, despite the grave threats it poses to humanity, is not a tangible threat in the everyday lives of most Americans, even those who support taking action against it.

One of the major goals for all scientists, especially climate scientists, should be to capture the public consciousness. The conversation cannot be about intangibles like gradual sea level rise. It must be about immediate consequences. Fundamentally, it needs to be a story about unmitigated human catastrophe. Too many scientists see their work as ending in the lab. But the modern scientist has a duty to engage the public too. Figures like Neil deGrasse Tyson should be the norm rather than the exception. I hope the future scientists of my generation, including me, take this responsibility more seriously.

David Swartout

Michigan. February 22, 2016

First, your use of quote marks around the words scientist and expert simply exacerbates the situation. These people ARE scientists and experts! Do they have every answer to every question concerning climate change? No, but that is the way of science. What they do have is much more knowledge and expertise than you or I, or any of those political deniers out there. Therefore, we trust them until proven wrong.

Secondly, this kind of science does not lend itself to very short term predictions. We do not yet have the computational ability for the kind of analysis required to make a one year projection. Unfortunately, humankind has a very difficult time internalizing long term crises, which makes climate change deniers, especially for political gain, so reprehensible.

Fourteen

Boston February 22, 2016

Measurements in increments of years? - it is more complicated than that. The sea rise is not linear.

From the internet: While global sea levels have risen about 2.75 inches (7 centimeters) over the past 22 years, the west coast of the United States has not seen much of a rise in ocean levels. That's largely because of a long-time-scale weather pattern called the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, which is masking the global effect. That, however, could reverse in the coming years, Willis said.

"In the long run, we expect the sea levels on the west coast to catch up to global mean and even exceed the global mean," Willis said.

Florida is also particularly vulnerable to sea level rise because its porous soil allows more seawater intrusion than does the soil in other coastal areas, Willis said.

- Willis is an oceanographer at NASAs Jet Propulsion Lab.

Iver Thompson

Pasadena, CA February 22, 2016

For Pete's sake, when will scientists get it through their heads that when the characterize their dire-sounding predictions in time frames that are almost a hundred years out - rather than the urgency of the moment - most people will tend to do is sit back an think: So what, I'll be dead by then so why should I care?

If scientists and physicists can supposedly measure time down to a millionth of a second, certainly these environment scientists can come up with a framework that is more momentary that will convey the urgency today instead of way off in the future that no one presently living can relate to. Too bad if the science "isn't exact enough", make your science such that it is. Otherwise it's nothing more than advocating for the predictable "kicking of the can down the road" that's so fashionable these days?

Sometimes it's hard not to blame the naysayers for their apathy when their given data that's almost at the point of abstraction because it isn't within a context they can relate to personally - like their life spans! Scientists ever heard of Public Relations? It's essentially what makes the world go round these days, or in this case maybe save it to keep going round, assuming the message makes the case for it.

Andy W

Chicago, Il February 22, 2016

Though cars are only part of the picture, all you skeptics out there need to realize what happens with each tank. Depending on what kind of gas you are burning, every gallon puts 16 to 22 lbs of carbon dioxide into the air. Take a billion cars around the world each burning from a few to twenty plus gallons per day and multiply. All that CO2 goes somewhere people and there is only so much atmosphere. Now, add in industry, carbon fueled power plants and everything else we do. To say we have a minimal impact on global temperature variations is simply ludicrous.

  • Flag
  • 7Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

tom c

daytona beach, fl February 22, 2016

Andy...a gallon of gasoline weighs 8 lbs.....but you claim it puts 16 to 22 lbs of co2 into the air.......could you explain your math on this?

  • Flag
  • 2Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Steve C

Greenfield Ctr February 22, 2016

You answered your own question. A gallon of gas weighs (a bit less than) 8 lb. About 85% of that weight, or almost 7 lb, is carbon. (The rest is hydrogen.) But to make CO2 out of 7 lb of carbon, you have to add about 18 lb of oxygen, which comes from the air. Bingo, roughly 25 lb of CO2 from a gallon of gas. Basic high school chemistry (from a HS physics teacher).

  • Flag
  • 7Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Patrick

Long Island N.Y. February 22, 2016

C'mon, High school science!

CO2.......a carbon atom and 2 Oxygen atoms remain from the chemical reaction between the Hydrocarbon fuel and Oxygen.

Gas alone weighs "X". Gas PLUS Oxygen weighs more.

Out of the tailpipe you get the byproducts Carbon Dioxide and water among some lesser gases.

  • Flag
  • 1Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Roger

New Jersey February 22, 2016

"They also knew that the sea level had basically stabilized, like the rest of the climate, over the past several thousand years"

Well, in truth there have been dramatic climate shifts within the historical period which have gone so far as to determine the rise and fall of entire civilizations. The archaeological record bears witness to these events. Pre-industrial civilization was far more susceptible to the effects of changes, which could cause massive famines, deadly disease outbreaks and other population catastrophes.

“as the Industrial Revolution took hold, the oceans began to rise”

Not quite. We simply don’t have accurate records from the pre-industrial period. Sea level is notoriously difficult to measure, and no one knows what the rate of sea level rise was in 1740 a.d., much less 865 a.d. or 420 b.c.

“The seas are rising at what appears to be an accelerating pace”

What “appears,” but still no. The rate of sea level rise, according to the tide gauges, has been more or less constant at 1.8 mm/yr over the past century or more. The satellites show 3.1 mm/yr, and the discrepancy has not been adequately accounted for or explained.

  • Flag
  • 4Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Geoff

Whistler Canada February 22, 2016

Roger

@Geoff -- that's not always reliable. For example, there are many ruins of ancient seaports which are now far inland, but this is often due to silting rather than sea level fall.

  • Flag

Jonathan Katz

St. Louis February 22, 2016

What is the news here? Sea level is rising "by about a foot per century". That's not news; it has been known, on the basis of precise satellite measurements, for decades.

Rahmsdorf has changed the upper limit of his predictions (for 2100) from "5--6" feet to "3--4" feet. That's a reduction, certainly not what the article title would lead one to expect. Those are only his predictions, and an upper limit to them; it could well be less. Perhaps the present rate of rise will continue, in which case it will be about one foot by 2100. Not a catastrophe.

Sarah

Santa Rosa Ca February 22, 2016

As a high school science teacher it is so frightening for me to listen to young people who do not believe in climate change. They react to it as if it just politics and not actual science. I feel so frightened for the next generation especially because many politicians here in the United States are putting up so many roadblocks to truly tackling this crisis.

I just had a conversation with a woman from Fiji who relayed that all young people in Fiji are activists in the fight against climate change. She asked me if I addressed the issue in my classroom and although I do I did need to tell her that many of my students are not receptive to the information. Every day in Fiji these young people see the effects of a process that they did little or nothing to contribute to. Their entire way of life is threatened and yet here in the US we continue to have a large carbon footprint due to ignorance and selfishness.

But I'll just keep on teaching and hoping to educate more young people despite the plethora of misinformation from the Republican politicians.

"The shattered water made a misty din.
Great waves looked over others coming in,
And thought of doing something to the shore
That water never did to land before.
The clouds were low and hair in the skies,
Like locks blown forward in the gleam of eyes.
You could not tell, and yet it looked as if
The shore was lucky in being backed by cliff,
The cliff in being backed by continent.
It looked as if a night of dark intent
Was coming, and not only a night, an age.
Someone had better be prepared for rage.
There would be more than ocean-water broken
Before God's last Put out the light was spoken."
-- Robert Frost, 1928

Susan Anderson

is a trusted commenter Boston February 22, 2016

I live ~5 feet above sea level, since 1980. I've been watching floods and taking pictures and I can assure any doubters that while the increase was subtle and inconsistent in the beginning, it is now obvious that *every* flood tide is higher than the big flood tides used to be. I will have to move in 5 or 10 years. Meanwhile, highrises are going up and much of the city, like many other US cities, is similarly low. Profiteers are not interested in the future, they just loot and leave, like frackers and others.

If one is obese, first one needs to stop the rate of increase, then slow, then level off, then begin to reduce. Acceleration is like that, and the reductions lately have only been reductions in the rate of increase. Following the obesity metaphor, that's mostly gain.

People seem unable to comprehend that increase is a slow process until it isn't any more. We are on the cusp of a more noticeable increase, and the cause of it is a delayed effect, so even with action now we have accepted an unacceptable level of climate chaos.

It's really pretty simple: we are accumulating heat-trapping greenhouse gases in our atmosphere, which are increasing the energy (heat) in the system (global warming) which is disrupting our global circulation (climate change).

At this point, we are also experiencing a gross increase in overall moisture, meaning that every storm is bigger than predicted, because predictions are based on historical data, which have been "trumped" by reality.

  • 33Recommend

penna095

pennsylvania February 22, 2016

The Little Ice Age ended in 1850, the earth has been gradually warming since. Everyone knows this from schooldays

That human activity might be helping it along can be easily seen on a summer day, in a population center (China has over 40 cities with a population over one million, USA has 10) by walking out of the population center. It is cooler away from the city.

"The sea is come up upon Babylon: she is covered with the multitude of the waves" Jer. 51:42

Rik Myslewski

San Francisco February 22, 2016

It’s inarguable that the vast majority of qualified scientific associations and individuals understand and can provide well-supported and empirically proven logic to prove AGW, and it’s also inarguable that the Heartland Institute and other anti-AGW apologists (Willie Soon, Bjørn Lomborg, et al.) are supported by fossil-fuel industry interests.

C’mon, folks, grow a pair. The simple fact is that we're causing climate change, heating the earth’s surface and troposphere, acidifying the ocean, transferring heat into the deep ocean, decreasing the arctic albedo, and destabilizing glaciers and ice sheets. It's no longer arguable. It's a fact.

It’s also a problem — a big, but not insurmountable problem. It needs you all of us to face facts and come up with solutions. Climate contrarians would simply prefer to ignore the well-vetted and carefully analyzed science created — and thoroughly argued over, trust me — by thousands of researchers from a broad range of countries. Many go as far as to imply that all of their work is somehow an insanely complex and conspiratorial fraud — a change that is not only ludicrous on its face, but also more than a little insulting. And silly.

Folks, we’ve got a problem. We’re smart Americans. We’re inventive. We’re innovative. We can fix it.

San Francisco, same for 200 years
http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/sltrends_station.shtml?stnid=9...

Brest, 220 years of same sea level rise.
http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/sltrends/sltrends_global_station.htm?st...

Yet scaremongers make it look like the sea levels started to rise with industrial emissions.

Fortunately Australia showed leadership and will fire ALL its clueless climate scientists.

It is high time for the US to do the same...

Roger

New Jersey February 22, 2016

Yes, you are correct re: sea levels. What happened was that the satellites showed a greater rate of rise, and this was conveniently interpreted as an acceleration rather than a curious paradox. In fact, even if we accept the satellite data, the rise is faster than can be accounted for by melting and volumetric increase of ocean water alone. Obviously there are other factors involved here of which we are only dimly aware but which deserve greater attention.

(The obvious inference to me is that if the tide gauges show 1.8 mm/yr, and the satellites 3.1 mm/yr, the land must be rising too. But we never are shown "land rise" data, apart from a few so-called glacial rebound cases, and a mention or two of coastal subsidence).

  • Flag
  • 1Recommend

JohnJ

3). 95% of the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere comes from water vapor, which humans don't impact.

NorthXNW

West Coast February 22, 2016

I am a skeptic. This past Fall NOAA issued a winter forecast, prediction, for my region of the country the Pacific Northwest. NOAA said it was going to be a warm and dry winter (go to NOAA's website and check it out for yourself) yet this winter the Pacific Northwest has broken the all time historical record for rain. So the models used by NOAA are obviously wrong, they can't predict with certainty 6 months out, that's why I'm skeptical when others ask me to trust predictions that span decades and centuries.

I will get behind climate change but I will withhold getting excited. I expect the climate will change in the future, man-made or not, and keep an open ear to those who disagree the world is ending. I will remain calm.

Robert

Massachusetts February 22, 2016

Thank you nytimes for your coverage of the science of climate change. It encourages non-experts who know little of nothing of the dynamics of climate change to listen, and to support the role of scientific experts. This reportage is as essential as the science it explains -- our current challenge is to 'think like a planet.' Just for a little context, we earth scientists have been tracking this terrain for quite a while. In my 1982 graduate glaciology class we discussed our expectation, more speculation than substantiated with actual data, that sea level would rise precipitously by 2100. At that time, the trends in CO2 data from ice cores were pretty clear, the thermodynamics of CO2 in the atmosphere were very clear, and the geologic record of 'perched' beaches extremely clear. Ice sheets come and go, and have done so for a very long time.

Linda

is a trusted commenter Oklahoma February 22, 2016

The rise in sea level will affect more towns than just those on the coast. When I lived on the very southern end of Arkansas, at the spot where Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi come together, I used to kid my husband by saying we should buy property because, at the rate Louisiana was disappearing, it would one day be ocean front property. Then I saw a map of where the water would rise. The ocean water will back up into major rivers like the Mississippi and the Columbia on the west coast. Cities, like the one I lived in on the Mississippi River, will go under. Yes, even though my little town was hundreds of miles from the Gulf Coast, the water will rise enough to flood the Mississippi and cover the river towns. Towns like Greenville, Mississippi and the little town I lived in, Lake Village, Arkansas, will go under water.

  • 5Recommend

MyTwoCents

San Francisco February 22, 2016

"...at the rate Louisiana was disappearing,.."

Yes, official data indeed shows Louisiana sea levels are rising faster than average. In fact, along the whole East Coast (and South Coast), sea levels are rising much faster than on the West Coast. In some places in Oregon and (especially) Alaska, sea levels have actually been falling. One would think sea level is the same everywhere, but clearly it's not. That may be because "sea level" takes into account not only water level, but also land level. In some places, land level is rising faster than water level is, and so sea level is dropping.

That's not so in Louisiana, however.

jbsay

PA February 23, 2016

In 4B years the Sun will become a red giant and everyone will die.
Any time in the next 10,000 years we could exit the interglacial and much of the earth will be covered with ice for over 100,000 years.
At any time a planet killer asteroid could strike and exterminate all life on earth.

These and myriads of other disasters are possible and yet we are doing nothing to protect our children, or childrens children from them.

In the 18th century Malthus predicted overpopulation and mass starvation, Ehrlich did so again in the 1960's.
Today there are near 8B people, the standard of living has doubled since Ehrlich, and increased many times over since Malthus.
Starvation only exists as a function of politics not food supply. Humans consume nearly double the calories they did in the 1960's. Life spans have increased many times since Malthus.

In fact every single one of these "malthusian" predictions of doom, has not only subsequently proven false - but wildly false.

Stephen

Santa Cruz, CA February 22, 2016

My father wrote the first paper showing that we are affecting the CO2 in the atmosphere in 1957 - Yes Roger Revelle got the credit, but as he was the director of SIO at the time, my father was happy to take 2nd place.
Anyway, I grew up hearing that once the ice starts melting it will happen very quickly... within a lifetime. I was also told that if you melted all the ice on the planet sea level would rise by 100 meters. This was all back of the envelope calculations. (The current calculation is something like 294 feet)
Since hearing all of this some 60 years ago, I've always been impressed by how the actual events have always been underestimated by the "experts". I assume this will continue so.
What too many people forget, and don't plan for, is that whatever the rise will be by centuries end, it will continue to rise for a long time. I've yet to see planners understand this... Most plan ahead 50 years and expect things to stop then. They don't plan a kind of program that has us continuously movie to higher ground over the next millennium or so....

  • Flag
  • 56Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Susan Anderson

is a trusted commenter Boston February 22, 2016

There's a very ugly story attached to that. Revelle was very sick and powerful deniers bullied him. Fact.

http://rabett.blogspot.com/2014/09/a-note-about-roger-revelle-julian.html

For starters:

"1. Fred Singer is the most unethical scientist, in my opinion, that I have ever met. I said so in the early 1990s, publicly, and I am still confident in the truth of this statement.

"2. The worst decision I ever made in my life was to provide a retraction of my statements in the early 1990s about Singer's nastiness. The retraction was coerced. It was required to stop the SLAPP suit brought against me by a conservative think-tank in Washington that wanted to keep Fred Singer in action.

"3. I was 95% certain that I would win my case in court. But my wife was terrified. In fact, she was terrorized by this lawsuit. We had three young children. I was a Harvard postdoc now needing to find a next academic posting. She was a graduate student at Harvard. My wife was worried about that 5% risk. She was scared we could lose our house and all our assets. We new it would be a 2-3 year ordeal that would drain our resources and attention. ... we couldn't afford the $100k+ that the lawsuit would cost. Defending for a year took an enormous amount of my time. That is the meanness and force of a SLAPP suit."

See link for a lot more.

For more about how the law is used to intimidate climate science, see Lamar Smith, Ted Cruz, and Judicial Watch, using Congress's power to intimidate the facts.

Better mosquito repellents. And rat killers. Rats do love a waterfront.

Hydroponic farming in a saline environment. Arid farming technologies for new deserts.

Long lasting caulks and sealants.

The free market loves a challenge, as long as that challenge is *not* addressing climate change.

NYT Pick

Jack Belicic

Santa Mira February 22, 2016

The practical public policy question is this: how many billions will the taxpayers be forced to waste in building useless seawalls, levees, beaches and the like, and insuring property at-risk, until New Orleans, Miami Beach and etc. are finally underwater? How long do we allow the politicians to buy votes with our money and waste the cash that could be much better-spent on orderly relocation, construction of infrastructure for new cities and etc. The governments are quick to tax us more and more and use "climate change" as the excuse, while the money is dumped into the rising tides to no effect.

  • Flag
  • 172Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Mal Adapted

Oregon February 22, 2016

Jack Belicic,

A *revenue-neutral* carbon tax, charged to producers at the source and paired with a Border Tax Adjustment on imported goods, would harness market forces to drive the transition to a carbon-neutral economy in a few decades, without dumping any money into the rising tides. Before you respond with the usual knee-jerk anti-tax arguments, do yourself a favor and take a look at carbontax.org.

Contrary to chicken little nonsense on net a warmer planet is a better planet.

What is unfortunate is that even the predicted Sea Level rise will not put New York or other bastions of left wing idiocy underwater.

The mathematical odds of the global climate models being correct given the discrepancy between current temperatures and predicted temperatures is less than 3% - yet 95% of IPCC scientists think the models are correct.
Did any of these climate scientists pass high school statistics ?
Do we determine reality based on a poll of climate scientists ?

We should be praying for the warming we are unfortunately unlikely to get.
A warmer world is on NET a better world.

Yossarian

Heller, USA February 22, 2016

So what? Two variables that now exist that didn't exist then: lots more humans (and their livestock -- methane gas emissions from livestock adds to the problem) and the huge amounts of green house gas those humans are spewing. So while you may be correct about long term climate fluctuations in the distant past, they occurred over long periods before the existence or prevalence of these variables.

Dr. M

  • Flag
  • 2Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Dr. Donny

Colorado February 22, 2016

It is worth noting that if one considers tidal gauge records for the 20th century and TOPEX satellite altimetry data for recent decades, the average sea level rise was about 8 inches/century over that time interval. This data does not show any significant recent non-linear trend which would cause it to rise to 'three to four feet' for the 21st century as the authors claim. No one would argue that such a rate is not possible, but it would be nice to know the authors assumptions for making predictions which are clearly out of line with past data that included the time interval of Industrial Era temperature rise. When one adds in the observed stasis in global temperature for almost two decades now, confirmatory studies would be in order before making any rash conclusions.

Mal Adapted

Pangold: "When Freeman Dyson says your maths are bollix -- they likely are. "

Ah, the fallacious argument from authority. Dr. Dyson has admitted he hasn't taken the time to examine all the evidence for anthropogenic global warming. When there's a lopsided consensus of working climate scientists, who have taken the time to examine all the evidence, that climate change is caused by man, I'm inclined to think that what Freeman Dyson says is "bollix".

Mal Adapted

Oregon February 22, 2016

CMK,

We'll have to adapt to the warming that's already occurred, but all that's lacking to prevent more warming is political will. A carbon tax on fossil fuels, charged to producers and matched with a Border Tax Adjustment on imported goods, would drive the transition to a carbon-neutral economy with alacrity. Money is being put into disaster planning, but if we put money into stopping the release of fossil carbon into the atmosphere, we'd have less disaster to plan for.

Cody

Australia February 23, 2016

Your last sentence is erroneous, "It mustn't be how they warn it will be because otherwise my response would be different to my current response".

In fact, among climate science circles, scientists are pushing for more (realistic) doomsday scenarios - the consensus is that we will definitely not, by any measure, be 'okay'. This reality is so much the case that many climate scientists are increasingly showing PTSD-like symptoms due to the stressful/hopeless nature of their work (do a search on that for sources). Simply assuming that something can't be true because otherwise your reaction would be different to how it is now is not an argument.

  • 2Recommend

Chip Steiner

Lenoir, NC February 23, 2016

Perhaps a point was missed WKO. Ice melts when temperatures go up. Increasing temperatures, slow or fast, mean rising ocean levels. How slow do you think we should go in changing behaviors and implementing as yet unknown technologies? Even if we were capable of stopping all global warming instantly, it would take decades, perhaps centuries, to see the results. That's fine and dandy for us (although your progeny may find your tombstone under lots of saltwater). It's not so fine for future generations.

And it isn't just that coastal cities might have to be relocated. Global warming will affect food resources, air quality, infrastructure--i.e. every element of human life--in very negative ways. That will certainly lead to much wider suffering and more wars as people fight over limited resources.

Going slow ain't gonna cut it.

  • Flag

DMATH

East Hampton, NY February 23, 2016

Nonsense, WKO. Your casual attitude is analogous to waiting until you are 55 years old to start saving for retirement. As we continue to pour CO2 into the atmosphere, we make the problem harder to solve and incur greater damage that must be paid for along the way. The basis for your attitude is twofold: first, you'd a rather your children sacrificed rather than you be inconvenienced; and second, you believe the propaganda that addressing climate change will destroy the economy, when in fact, studies have shown that the second industrial revolution of conversion to renewable sources of energy will stimulate the economy. See Citizensclimate lobby.org.

  • Flag
  • 2Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

pjc

Cleveland February 22, 2016

I remember in college reading about the early Mesopotamian civilizations, the great early cities along the Tigris and Euphrates, and felt a deep sadness as I learned, that the irrigation and farming methods of that time over the centuries eventually despoiled that amazingly fertile region, and the soil became barren. The humans of that early age and place essentially salted their own fields over time, and the civilizations faded as the fields along the rivers were gradually sapped of their ability to support agriculture.

And to this day, that great and vast valley, one of the cradles of civilization, is a desert.

I still cannot wrap my head around the fact, that while the fate of ancient Mesopotamia can be ascribed to lack of knowledge, human beings are such that they are equally adept at destruction of their own habitats via indifference to knowledge.

  • Flag

MDCooks8

West of the Hudson February 22, 2016

One question that I will raise again is why is there less emphasis on developing plans, strategies and actual methods for "adaptation" to changes in the environment other than only reducing greenhouse gases, when it may be virtually impossible to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to levels feasible to prevent the tides to rise?

Isn't "adaptation" inherit in human nature, as well as in other species that learn to survive changes. It would be safe to say that virtually every scientist providing research into climate change knows of Darwin and his "theory of evolution" so why is there less emphasis on "other means of adaptation to climate change" ?

Is it the media, like the NY Times and other stewards of both the media and social responsibility intentionally subduing the alternatives since it is less popular? And the same goes for politicians on the US and abroad down playing this as well.

During the Paris Climate Change conference, representatives from the Netherlands ( I do not recall their exact role if they are scientists, planners, etc.) had little if any participation in the conference to present alternate means and plans against rising waters due to climate change. These representatives indicate the Dutch have nearly 400 years of adapting to rising waters since most of the Netherlands is below sea level.
Are we placing all the eggs in one basket by not giving equal attention to alternate means to combat the effects of climate change, if rising tides are inevitable.

  • Flag
  • 3Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Lou Argyres

El Cerrito, CA February 22, 2016

"Adaptation" will look like Flint Michigan. Birds and the bees now, thousands and then millions sacrificed later.

  • Flag
  • 4Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Maggie Norris

California February 22, 2016

Your understanding of evolution is extremely shallow. "Adaptation" in the Darwinian sense has absolutely nothing tondo with "learning." It has almost absolutely nothing to do with anything any creature does in its lifetime. Any meaningful adaptation happens over thousands of generations, i.e., hundreds of thousands of years. ( Human adaptation to agriculture is a very special case that took only a few hundred generations. Or, looking at it another way, adaptation to agriculture failed to happen, and the human species will become extinct only a few thousand years after the invention of agriculture.) Adaptation to warmer temperatures will happen. Part of it will be the demise of the human species, to be replaced by species adapted to the new conditions created by the human species on their way to rapid extinction.

  • Flag

NYT Pick

casual observer

Los angeles February 22, 2016

The rising of the seas by four feet would be very destructive. Until the mid nineteenth century roads were hard to maintain and most trade was carried on by waterways including over oceans. This means that the most endangered human works are very substantial, including all great cities on oceans and many on rivers with outlets to oceans. It will cost so much to preserve or to relocate all this that the economy of the world will be devoted to in for many decades. It will provide work but and new opportunities to make new wealth but the existing wealth destroyed will be beyond reasonable estimating. To control the rise of the seas by eliminating most of the emissions of carbon gases would be worthwhile, for those people who would be affected.

The problem is that very few of those people who will be affected have been born, and nearly all alive will not be affected. How can it be justified to make living people sacrifice their wealth, time, and efforts on things that benefit people who they have never met and may never meet?

NYT Pick

casual observer

Los angeles February 22, 2016

Are people obliged to alter the way they live because of how it might or not affect people who are not yet alive, if it causes them to live less well, if it costs them being able to live as comfortably as their previous efforts allow them? As parents and grandparents they have a natural concern for their offspring and probably their offspring's offspring but it become difficult to emphasize with abstractions rather than real people. It is especially problematic when it seems that they and their offspring may have to sacrifice for people that have yet to be born. The needs of now will tend to come first in most people's priorities.

"How can it be justified to make living people sacrifice their wealth, time, and efforts on things that benefit people who they have never met and may never meet?"

Because God (or evolution, if you prefer) has given us big brains and with them, the ability to reason in abstract concepts beyond our own immediate needs. Because we are capable of compassion, empathy, and love for fellow people, no matter their distance from us in time or space. Of all species on the planet, we alone are capable of this! Because it is uniquely human to consider the future of our species, and not just ourselves.

SMS

Rhinebeck, NY February 23, 2016

I take it that your family line stops with you: no children, no grandchildren.

Many concerned people take a longer view with regard to their families down the generations.

Of course there is another reason to be concerned. Are we our brothers' (and sisters') keepers, or not--using the expression in a broad sense? Is there such a thing as a world-wide human family, not just now, but ongoing?

The benefits of the present civilization I've enjoyed in the US and abroad for the last eight decades are the result of many generations before me, forward-thinking and generous-minded people long, long ago, people I've never even heard of.

We don't own this earth. We are merely stewards of it.

The sea rises one inch, but all depending on the profile of the coastal areas, up to half a mile or even more will be flooded either permanently or during the slightest storm surge. You can't build a dam high enough to keep the water out, unless you want to build a dam all around your nation.

The younger one is, the greater the effects one will suffer. Connect the dots.

Only the exercise of human imagination and empathy can motivate us to act for the benefit of our unborn descendants.

Those capacities spring naturally from appreciating, moment-to-moment, how the grandeur and vastness of experience dwarf and transcend our individual life-spans.

It's not something to think about. It's something to cultivate over the years, a way of being.

msf

We are NOW affected, and it is OUR generation that has to research - and yes: you can call it sacrifice - or you can call it reducing our insane consumerism.
You may not be affected in your own house, but look at the cost to society of disaster spending, of security measures (terrorism and destabilized societies), of waves of fugitives (Europe, Central America). Just add up what the US government alone had to spend on Katrina, Sandy, wildfires, drought, storms (which in their strength + frequency can be attributed to climate change). That is money that was not spent on health, education, infrastructure. So YES, we are starting to be affected. And small sacrifices today will hopefully prevent devastating sacrifices in 20 years.

I would love a reply if this comment resonates with you.

NYT Pick

ProfessorBrooks

Florida February 23, 2016

Your comment reminds me that medieval period built Gothic cathedrals that often took over a century to complete. The builders who began a cathedral project, and the townspeople and church who began paying for it, knew they would not live to see its completion--their great-grandchildren enjoyed the masterpieces of their ancestors who did so out of devotion to God. Perhaps if we can muster something of the same reverence for the planet, along with concern for our species, we may be capable of the great work lying ahead of us.

If forecasters are correct, the likelihood of a summer mosquito deluge is probable. Then consider a hatchery of diseased bloodsuckers on land the city permitted for development without a place for the larvae infested water to go. With the rainy hurricane season approaching, Pinecrest has provided a service no other city has so readily offered: a mosquito refuge, a sanctuary for disease carrying invertebrates. See for yourself:

http://pinecrestfloods.blogspot.com/

There is inland sea rise and coastal, they go together along with the emissions and other environmental sins. Yet home prices keep rising and rising, must be that Middle Ages mindset.

These critical sources for fresh water will, one by one, become unfit for use as our community water supply.

Discernie

Antigua, Guatemala February 22, 2016

That is what we have from what little we know.

When we learn how the various systems work with one another and how the interactive picture coalesces it will likely be too late. Too many factors unknown to interpolate into the global weather future will be our ultimate downfall. Studying pieces does not provide a comprehensive gestalt of what we face.
As we become more aware as to how systems impact and one effects and interacts with the other, our projection for cataclysmic events will become more dim and eventually will culminate in a global ecological wipeout in relatively short order. I'd hazard to say within the next 20-30 years we will encounter forces we have unleashed as humans that will disrupt all life on earth as to make our future highly untenable if not close to oblivion. Add some nuclear strikes and you have a formula for the very end.

Look a few years back an old friend Black Elk said:

Hey! Lean to hear my feeble voice.
At the centre of the sacred hoop
You have said that I should make the tree to bloom.
With tears running, O Great Spirit, my Grandfather,
With running eyes I must say
The tree has never bloomed

Here I stand, and the tree is withered.
Again, I recall the great vision you gave me.

It may be that some little root of the sacred tree still lives.
Nourish it then
That it may leaf
And bloom
And fill with singing birds!

Hear me, that the people may once again
Find the good road
And the shielding tree.

WHERE IS THE SHIELDING TREE?

But "scientist" have to sell it as real and accurate if they want more money. As an engineer I used similar model methodology to design airplanes- stress analysis and aerodynamics but we always built and flew a prototype because we new the results were never going to be 100% accurate.

Bruce Rozenblit

is a trusted commenter Kansas City February 22, 2016

Our capitalistic society is governed by markets. That means we wont change our behavior until it costs us money, usually big money. The effects of global warming are not producing losses large enough for us to take evasive action. The way our system works is that it prioritizes todays profits at the expense of profits many years from now. If we were to impose a carbon tax (a super idea) to change our behavior, the money people start screaming about Marxism, and socialism and the end of freedom.

The loss of freedom from a carbon tax pales in comparison to the losses caused by flooding of shoreline property, loss of fresh water, crop failures and a surge of tropical insect born diseases. Since those haven't hit yet, no action will be taken.

We only have one planet. We all have to share it. Unlimited personal freedom must be tempered by that sharing to the point that we don't burn the place up. If we don't begin to cooperate with each other and make some small compromises today, nature will force us to make huge compromises decades from now. There is more to living than just generating profits. Global warming will keep people from living.

casual observer

Los angeles February 22, 2016

We, human kind, must address this problem to both protect what exists in the biosphere on which quality of life and survival depend, to avoid most of the pending mass extinctions that are likely to occur, and to avoid pandemics, famine, war over resources, and the catastrophic effects upon the means we use to live. We the people alive, today, may never experience the possible consequences that would occur in over three quarters of a century whether or not we act, but the costs of changing everything that we do could keep us living like people at war or recovering from great devastating natural disasters for the entire lifetimes of people during this century.

Bruce

The World February 22, 2016

Glaciers are melting because of what we started to do 250 - 300 years ago. But we have more than doubled down on what we do, with the result that even were we to bring our carbon emissions down to 1800 levels, the melting will continue, although it might slow after 100 or more years. It is obvious you know nothing about feedback loops and the fact that triggers and trigger points are a feature of them. The problem with climate science is we know the trigger points are there, but we don't know where. That's why some things are happening earlier (faster) than scientists' models predicted, while others are happening later (slower). But when 98% of scientists agree - even those employed by Exxon-Mobil - that this is happening, only fools deny it. The more fool you, because the ones who will suffer the effects are your kids/grandkids/great-grandkids.

Neweryorker

Brooklyn February 22, 2016

For more balanced journalism - offering more than one point of view, for example - the article could also offer the recent NASA study showing that the seas are rising much more slowly than predicted, due in part to water absorption by land.

  • Flag
  • 7Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

JCG

San Diego February 22, 2016

Not "much more slowly" but more slowly than predicted due to the unanticipated water absorption by some areas of land with increased precipitation (caused by climate change). And, as the article points out, once the land becomes saturated in a not very long time (decades) the rise in sea level will resume its relentless progress at an increased pace, making up for lost time. In the final analysis, there will be no joy in Mudville no matter how much water the land tries to absorb.

  • Flag
  • 13Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Alex

Princeton, NJ February 22, 2016

You don't seem to need more "balanced" reporting, but simply more accurate reporting. The NASA study you are talking about does not say that sea level is rising "much more slowly than predicted". It says that land has been storing up water over the last 10 years. This study does not affect measurements of how fast sea level is rising, or how it compares to predictions. (One interpretation could be that without the land soaking up water, sea level rise would have risen even faster. )

Howard G

New York February 22, 2016

Guess what folks -

Our planet is a living organism unto itself, which - like any living being - has a most basic instinct of survival...

As the health of the organism is compromised by other invasive organisms (people) - who threaten its survival - the planet will takes the steps necessary to eliminate the invaders by way of creating its own "antibodies" - which appear in a number of different forms - such as pandemic diseases, natural disasters and - yes - climate change - in a attempt to create an environment which is uninhabitable and deadly to the invaders --

And -

It is the very height of hubris to turn this argument into a political discussion regarding who is to "blame" for creating this situation -

You can all enjoy batting around the ball of political debate with regard to our self-destruction of the planet - but meanwhile the Earth will continue to do whatever is required to ensure its health and survival...

Tomorrow - when you put out that festering bag of garbage - with its horrible stench - on the curbside in a "politically correct" container - keep in mind that you are making your contribution to the forward motion of this scheme -

And -- telling yourself that most of your non-recyclable garbage is "organic" - and will eventually find its way happily back to the soil - where it begins the "cycle" again is just a poor and tired exercise in feel-goodism - and denial...

Mal Adapted

Oregon February 22, 2016

Baron George Wragell,

Do you think climate scientists want to tell people what they can and can't do? Why do you expect an oceanographer to talk about cap and trade?

There's a lopsided consensus of working climate scientists -- you know, the people who've put the time in to understand the principles, examine all the evidence and discuss it all with each other until they're pretty sure they're not fooling themselves -- that the earth is warming and that humans are the cause. Denying the scientific consensus isn't going to make the problem go away. It's up to the rest of us to decide what to do about it.

nobrainer

New Jersey February 22, 2016

What is not discussed is phase change in water. Water can be ice or water at 0 Degrees Centigrade with the water phase having 80 Degrees Centigrade more of energy. The boiling point of water is 100 Degrees Centigrade. Temperature is misleading. The more important factor is how much energy is in the atmosphere. This effects storms much more than temperature.

  • Flag
  • 2Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Joe From Boston

Massachusetts February 22, 2016

What IS a nobrainer is that the change in phase from ICE to LIQUID WATER requires adding 80 calories per gram to the ice, not 80 degrees Centigrade.

The phase change from liquid water to water vapor at 100 degrees C requires adding 540 calories per gram of energy to the liquid water.

It takes 100 calories per gram to heat liquid water from 0 C to 100 C.

All of the bove is at 1 atmoshere of pressure.

  • Flag
  • 2Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Mal Adapted

Oregon February 22, 2016

nobrainer:

You can be sure phase change in water is quite well understood by the scientists looking at sea level rise. This is a newspaper article. Anyone who wants to know more detail can read the PNAS paper by clicking the link to it in the article. It's freely available without registration.

B.D.

Topeka, KS February 23, 2016

I'm more worried that they are making the data fit they hypothesis rather than real science. If you manufacturer the test to fit something you can't test--like sea levels in Roman times--then you're giving me Oprah Winfrey data, not science. None of these studies, none of them, explain temperature variations and extremes that existed in the 30's or the 70's. None of them account for natural climate change formulations that show the opposite. The Times itself reported a study last summer of a California drought study that concluded that state may, in fact, be reverting to the mean--a 50 million year mean--rather than encountering global warming. One could make the same statements about theories that wen the other way during colder periods in the past two centuries. This is indeed junk science, and one day it will be shown so, and then where will the stories be? I'm betting mea culpa.

E Adler

You shouldn't guage the effect of warming on sea level today by using figures for seal level rise at the end of ice ages. At the peak of the ice ages the volume of glaciers was enormous compared with today. Today, there is not enough ice on land to melt to raise sea levels by amounts that were seen during the end of ice ages.

Johnnie

The fact is that in gulf states the PRIMARY reason for sea level rise is man-made alright. We are pulling so much water and oil from the ground that sublimation the process of land settling as the water and oil are removed is causing INCHES of sea level rise per year compared to inches per century from global warming.

Finally, finally. Dont think that whatever happens can be blamed on big oil or some evil fossil fuel evil people. We are ALL the evil people because we need energy to survive and even if we cut all energy production or did whatever the Paris talks want us to do an analysis showed it would change the temperature in 2100 by an immeasurable amount. This is not about the blame game.
If there is actually any consequence worth spending two minutes on it is something we have to roll up our sleeves and get to doing mitigation. So, what are the answers? 1) There is a good business in lifting buildings. They have done it for centuries. 2) There is a lot of barriers technology to protect. 3) Lastly we are talking hundred years. Most buildings are rebuilt in < 100 years. They will simply have to rebuild higher or farther back or repurpose.

What I would never suggest is we help owners of bearchfront property in the future by compensating them. I am against that. Most beachfront property owners can take care of themselves. They are rich.

Alex

Princeton, NJ February 22, 2016

I appreciate the effort to put the new research in the context of previous studies, and to convey the crucial point that under continued high CO2 emissions, global warming, and its consequences like sea level rise, won't stop in 2100, as perhaps unfortunately implied by the usual time horizon of climate change projections - rather, sea level will keep rising for many centuries.   • Flag
  • 4Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Harold Green

Cleveland February 22, 2016

It all depends on which study you believe. Supposedly temperatures have stabilized for over a decade now which is why they changed global warming to climate change. Personally I have lived along the texas coast for over sixty years and I don't see any increase in sea level here. What I do see and people here have been aware of for decades is subsidence. Without accurate ocean heights from space (and we have that today but not going back a hundred years) there's little that can be gained by saying areas along the sea are flooding more from rises in ocean height. Many low lying areas along the texas coast have actually dried up from the small addition of silt in some areas. Wind is still a major factor here in tide heights. I've seen many a marina with their launching ramps completely out of the water at low tide or with an outgoing wind blowing the water out to sea. We have a lot of beach homes here that sit only two or three feet above high tide and that's pretty much where the tide was when they were built long ago. I'd like to say to all the harbingers of doom, watch the oceans and the beaches for a few decades before bad mouthing those who deny all the warnings.

John Wise

Ontario February 22, 2016

Temperatures have not stabilized and continue to go up. The last 3 years were the warmest on record.
"They" did not change global warming to climate change. Both terms have been used in the scientific literature for decades. They mean different things. Global warming is caused by the emissions from burning fossil fuels. This increase in atmospheric and ocean temperature leads to climate changes.

  • Flag
  • 2Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Mal Adapted

Oregon February 22, 2016

Harold Green: "It all depends on which study you believe."

Sure. Of course, some studies are more credible than others. Do you think you can tell a good study from a bad one? If you haven't put the time in to understand the basic principles and examine all the evidence on a scientific issue, you have no choice but to listen to the experts. How do you know who the genuine experts are?

Texas State Climatologist John Nielsen-Gammon calls the ability to judge expert credibility "Scientific Meta-literacy". Very few people can be specialists in any field of science, so we rely on knowledge of scientific culture and practice for clues to the credibility of information. We know, for example, that the National Academy of Sciences is a more trustworthy source than a think-tank funded by fossil-fuel billionaires. A transcript of Dr. Nielsen-Gammon's talk at the American Geophysical Union 2012 annual meeting is on his blog:

http://blog.chron.com/climateabyss/2013/02/scientific-meta-literacy/

  • 4Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Steve Bolger

New York City February 22, 2016

The normal difference between low and high tides along the northeast Massachusetts coastline can range up to 13 feet from astronomical effects alone. Weather effects can add feet to that. This obviously dwarfs the slow rise of average sea level around the globe. But rising average sea level may increase the amplitude of tides too.
