S.D.Keith

Birmigham, AL February 22, 2016

It is not a scientifically-valid statement to simply state that seas are rising at the fastest rate in the last 28 centuries because of mankind's activity. First, the claim that seas are actually rising must be scientifically vetted. Then the cause, among many thousands or even millions, must be teased out. It takes further inquiry to ascertain the cause of the cause. To connect A, rising sea levels, to C, mankind's activity, without going through B, the immediate cause of the sea level rise is not science but speculation.

Proving A is difficult enough. Anecdotal evidence of coastal flooding in cities built along coastlines is not enough. Proving B if A is proved is nigh well scientifically impossible given the number of variables at play. And proving C to a level of scientific certainty is about as hard as proving B.

So they might as well go ahead and make the leap, claiming that sea levels are rising due to mankind's influence on the climate. The whole thing is just conjecture and mythology and speculation dressed up as science.

And lest there be any doubt it is more a matter of belief than of science, pay careful mind to how anyone like me who dares question the catechism is treated. The pejoratives flow--denialist, Neanderthal, flat-earther, etc. I just wish they'd call me a skeptic, or, maybe a heretic, because I don't worship at the altar of mankind-induced climate change. This ain't science. It's more akin to religion.

  • Flag
  • 6Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

 February 22, 2016

Grand Rapids, Mi February 22, 2016

  • Flag

James

Denver CO February 22, 2016

Let's agree. The science is not definitive. No one can say with 100% certainty that sea level will rise 3-4 feet in 2100. But you're missing the point, which is that the vast majority of scientists have concluded that there is a significant possibility that we are creating a condition that will cause a huge amount of suffering and dislocation. You don't have to be 100% convinced of this to conclude that it is prudent to try to do something to prevent it. If you were only 50% sure that ISIS was planning to explode a bomb in Times Square, would you do nothing? Dick Cheney said we were obligated to do everything possible if the chance of a repeat of 9/11 was only 1%. So why don't we face this threat with the same attitude? It's reasonable to say that we should not go completely overboard in combatting the threat. It is not reasonable to say we should completely ignore the threat any more than it is reasonable to say we should completely ignore the threat of ISIS.

  • Flag

What's funny, I'm not all that opposed to reducing the effluents we put into our atmosphere, which I think is the main tenet of climate change crowd's catechism. But we can take good care of the earth without pretending we know what causes sea level fluctuations and temperature cycles. We can do so just because it's the right thing to do.

CityBumpkin

Earth February 22, 2016

The bizarre phenomenon of climate change denial underscores how important education and scientific literacy is to a modern democracy. Scientists are not mystics or priests. Scientists publish their findings in peer-reviewed publications, and part of the process is they explain how they got to their conclusions. Most of this information is available on the internet, available for anybody willing to take the time to look at it.

In other words, you don't have to take their word for it! They will and do explain how they arrived at their conclusions to anyone willing to take the time to follow their work. But no climate change denier I have ever met seems willing to take the time to do that.

Mal Adapted

Oregon February 22, 2016

HBM: "The NYTimes should also tell its readers that measuring sea level remains an immensely imprecise science. "

One thing is certain: if you got your information from primary scientific sources rather than science-denying blogs, you'd have a clearer picture of reality.

Most of us are well aware of that. Science knows very little with absolute certainty, but there are things that are known with high confidence. A rise in sea level of three to four feet by 2100 is one of them. You don't need to wait for the NYT to tell you that, you can consult NOAA, NASA, the USGS, or any number of academic earth science sites. If you don't trust them, why do you trust anyone else?

  • Flag
  • 1Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

CityBumpkin

Earth February 23, 2016

You seem to cling on to a few headlines without actually reading the contents. First, even the author of the paper publishing the study regarding Antarctic ice mass is not claiming this refutes existing evidence of global warming. If you read past the headlines, you'll see that the increase in ice mass is in inland areas and is a result of increased precipitation. Precipitation increases when there is an increase in the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere. Water vapor is both a product of increased temperature but also a greenhouse gas itself.

Second, as far as NASA can tell, rate of ice discharge into the ocean is still increasing. Western Antarctic ice is still melting.

Skepticism is good, but you need to read past the headlines. Don't just cling onto a few headlines that you think support your conspiracy theory.

Mal Adapted

Oregon February 22, 2016

Man with No Name: "As usual, all these predictions are projected beyond anyone's lifetime."

I don't know about you, but I can reasonably expect to live until 2050. Assuming a constant rate of sea level rise, I should see one-and-a-half to two feet by then.

"I'd love to see a prediction of sea levels ten years out."

Do the arithmetic: three to four feet by 2100 is 36 to 48 inches in 84 years. That's about four to six inches in ten years. Happy now?

Francesco Zerilli

Detroit February 22, 2016

There's not enough ice and snow on this planet that would even raise the sea levels one foot. First off, if you're worried about the North Pole melting, well, it's nothing but a giant ice cube floating in the Arctic sea and if global temperatures would get so high that it would melt, there would be no significant notice of a rise in seas since there's such a thing as "Archimedes Principle". Secondly, if you're worried about the Antarctic melting, keep in mind that the annual average temperature is -47 F which means there would have to be a constant temperature rise of 80 degrees F before it began to melt down, If that should be the case, it would indicate that this planet was knocked off its orbit and headed directly toward the sun and a rise in sea levels would be the least of our worries......LOL!

As a side note, glaciers grow and calve as a direct result of increased snow and ice pressure at their centers, not due to warmth which only occurs at their extreme edges.............

Warren

  • Flag
  • 1Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Rudy Ludeke

Falmouth, MA February 22, 2016

@Zerilli
I totally disagree with your statements as to no sea rise if all the worlds glacier melt. Here is a simple proof that even my middle school granddaughter could provide to you: Lets just talk about Greenland's ice cap melting: The data is easy to find:
Area of ice coverage of Greenland is 90% of its total area or about 2 million square kilometers with an average thickness ranging between 1.5 and 4.3 Km. For the sake of discussion we pick an average of about 3 Km = 3000 meters. The area of the world's ocean is 360 million square kilometers. The ratio of Greenland's area and that of the oceans is 2,000,000/360000000 = 0.0055. Making the simple, but reasonable assumption that there is little volume change upon melting, then the sea rise, if all of Greenland's ice melts is simply
3000 m X 0.0055 = 16.7 meters or about 55 feet!
So even if the thickness were half of that estimated, it still would yield a sea rise of 28 feet. There will be an additional rise as the underwater land portion of Greenland surges upwards (rebounds). Now if the antartic ice would melt...................

  • Flag
  • 1Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

michjas

Phoenix February 22, 2016

Unfortunately, climate science has become a matter that is extremely controversial. In order to have any effect, a consensus of scientists must speak out. Here we have a headline referring to "scientists", in general, which made me hope that the article would be reporting a consensus. Instead, it reports a single paper out of Germany and findings out of New Jersey that assume the German research is true. How important is it that Dr. Rahsmtorf "thinks we can definitely be confident" in his findings. Well, the guy isn't very articulate in English. Presumably, though, he's a leading scientist. Still, he falls way short of being a consensus.

I don't think the Times does climate change science any good by running this as a front page story and giving climate change deniers the opportunity to score points by attacking a single study, as they will surely do. Front page news in climate science unfortunately requires a consensus of belief. Until Mr. Ramstorf convinces the scientific community, his study deserves no more than a squib.

Dennis

Flushing, MI February 22, 2016

Dr. Rahmstorf is of course just a single scientist but that in no way lessens the importance of this article. He is extremely well respected in the field of climatological oceanography and his works are among the most cited in the field. In total, there are ten authors on this study. It is, analytically, not for the faint-hearted and includes over 100 references. If you want signs of a consensus, look at position statements on climate change taken by a wide variety of professional organizations (American Association for the Advancement of Science, American Chemical Society, American Geophysical Union, American Physical Society (Physics), American Meteorological Society...).

Fred

My father's side of the family is from the Eastern Shore of Virginia, a very narrow peninsula between the Chesapeake Bay and the Atlantic Ocean. Many relatives still live there. Many more are buried there. The question is when, not if, it will be submerged, along with much of the rest of the Eastern Shore of Maryland, much of Delaware... This is not merely projections by scientists. This is real people and real places, all over the world. It did not have to be this way, but it is. How do we prepare and how do we stop making it worse?

  • Flag
  • 7Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Norman

California February 22, 2016

Some facts:

California sea level has not risen in Fifteen Years (it may have receded for all I know) reported by Jerry Hill Calif State Senator and Global Warming and an advocate of the same.

The sea 'level' throughout the world has a variation of 300 feet so it must be hard to actually measure.

Using 'data' from thousands of years ago is foolhardy.

Chicago's temperature has hardly risen in 100 years. An extrapolation out another 100 years gets a temperature rise 0.04 degrees F.

The highest summer temperatures in the San Francisco Peninsula occurred in the 1970's.

What happened to all of those hurricanes we were supposed to be getting after Katrina?

If the experts know so much they should tell us how in the world did the North American Ice Age of 10,000 years ago which was so great it carved out the Great Lakes happen.

Experts? Bah humbug.

  • Flag
  • 2Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Bob Williamson

Woodridge IL February 22, 2016

I wonder how one would figure comparisons for the temperature of Chicago over the past 100 years. Over that time, the official readings were taken downtown (near the lake), then at the University of Chicago (also near the lake), then at Midway Airport (inland and southwest of downtown), and finally at O'Hare (also inland and northwest of downtown). If you live in Chicago, you know how different the temperatures can be among those sites. The facts might be a little complicated there.

This is really big news that will be bigger through the years. It should be part of the political discourse. You will never convince people to use less fossil fuels aside from effective regulation much like the efficiency standards for new cars, but you can tell them they have to move to higher ground.

I'm moving sooner or later.

casual observer

The people most likely to remain alive in 2100 are small children who have no grasp of the issues and will have no say in any decisions for another ten to twenty years. Most of the people who will suffer the worst effects are not born. To spend time working on issues that will not affect the vast majority of people now alive is to spend their lives and resources on things that cannot affect them, things that will affect strangers who they will not likely know. Given the current economic woes and the temptation to go all out on extracting, refining, and selling more and more fossil fuels, it might be that this discussion remains academic without any action taken for a long time.

The only challenge to wind and solar is now the intermittent nature of their output and that is being rapidly solved by battery storage

http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/news/2016/02/16/solarcity-to-use-tesl...

and by gravity based storage:

http://www.aresnorthamerica.com/grid-scale-energy-storage

nancy

indiana February 22, 2016

Indiana is a red state but with a warm winter our Lake Michigan level declines. The Lake counties are blue counties, though. The previous two winters were record cold winters and the lake rose 50 percentage points.

This winter is very warm and levels decrease because there is no ice acting as a blanket to stop evaporation.

The cause for the warm winter in our region is not just Global warming. It is El Niño and various Atlantic oscillations in pressure and surface temperatures.

Water vapor, salt or fresh water, ice, and air is quite complicated science.

Mal Adapted

Oregon February 22, 2016

Tom F,

The argument from consequences is a classic logical fallacy. What's required to solve the problem has nothing to do with whether there's a problem or not.

Before you can argue about solutions, you need to understand why there's a lopsided consensus of working climate scientists for anthropogenic global warming. To do that, you need to get your information from scientific sources, not science-denying blogs. If you don't trust climate scientists, why do you trust anyone?

Ted Obbard

Berkeley, CA February 22, 2016

The variable that the scientists cannot predict is how quickly and effectively humans respond. I am hopeful that we will convince Congress to put a fee on carbon and return the proceeds to American households - a non-partisan solution that would reduce our CO2 output by 50% in 20 years. Citizens Climate Lobby, the nonprofit citizen group that is pushing for it, is doubling in membership annually. (Extrapolate that!) Their work helped launch the Gibson Amendment (House Republicans declaring support for climate action) and the formation of the bipartisan House Climate Solutions Caucus. Whether the ice sheets collapse is up to us.

Nancy Parker

Englewood, FL February 22, 2016

Put your car on its end and drive it straight up at 60 mph. How long before you leave the earth's atmosphere?

The answer is 60 minutes. Yep, it's about 60 miles thin.

If you shrank the earth down to the size of a basketball, the atmosphere would be about the thickness of a sheet of plastic wrap clinging to the outside.

How much human activity do you think it takes to effect that thin sheet of protection around us - the air we breathe?

Only a few hundred years ago, not even a blink of the eye in geological times, every drop of oil on earth was in it.

Now, just close your eyes and think of the traffic in your town right this minute, and in the big city nearest you, and in the cities in your state, and all the states in the country 24/7, and in all the cities in the world, and all the new cars hitting the road ever day (1500 in Beijing ALONE), and then add in the buses and planes and manufacturing plants and the coal burning and electrical plants and.... how can a thinking person believe that we're NOT affecting that thin, thin layer of atmosphere?

At least admit that our efforts, as the single most successful species ever, who succeed not by adapting to different earthly environments but by changing them to adapt to us, are accelerating a natural process by multiples hard to imagine - with no time for plants or animals - ironically including us - to adapt to the changes we have wrought .

Cranky Yankee

Waves will lap at the remains of the steel and stone that has withstood the centuries of rising waters. They'll row their boats out to these ghosts of an era barely remembered - because that's where the good fishing is. The bravest among them will dive overboard to see if they can retrieve a totem from these ruins. Look around your office and your home today - and remember that some of these items may very well be sitting on an altar of a people whose lives we've changed. I wouldn't be surprised if they curse us, rather than honor us. And it didn't have to be like this...

Mal Adapted

Oregon February 22, 2016

Tom F,

You're making the argument from consequences, a classic logical fallacy. Just because anthropogenic global warming implies the need for government intervention to abate it, has nothing to do with whether climate science is credible. If you got your information from primary scientific sources rather than from AGW-denying blogs, you'd have a clearer picture of reality.

Whoever told you that climate scientists are "hoping to dupe gullible people" is lying. If you don't trust what climate scientists are telling you, why would you trust what AGW-deniers are telling you?

jzu

Cincinnati February 22, 2016

For those that dismiss anthropogenic global warming pointing to large scale changes between the ice ages. Let's be clear Homo sapiens in its current form will not inhabit the earth in 100,000 years or perhaps 10,000; for many reasons. The concern is how the next 10 generations of humans and mammals will live. What is threatening is not the fact that it is 5F warmer and the sea level is 50 feet higher. The problem is the rate of change (the first derivative). That rate of change is unprecedented. The mammalian population including Homo sapiens cannot adjust to fast change using the Darwinian mechanism. In addition, human infrastructure has grown over 100 years. Cities like New York and Mumbai, and Antwerp, ... will have to be moved at great cost and turmoil (call it war if you like). We will all need to develop capability against malaria, Dengue fever, etc; many of us will not and simply perish. Reducing CO2 emissions is cheaper, less cumbersome and more peaceful. What is so darn hard to understand about this?

Marc Whitehead

Portland, Oregon February 23, 2016

Yes, most folks do not realize or even want to consider how climate change will affect them and their future generations. We humans have established our lives and livelihoods according to the current existing climate. Warmer air, moister air, higher sea levels affect everything humans do. Do you commute to work?...Well, the culverts under your roads and the bridges over your rivers and your roads near the sea and along rivers were built for conditions that do not exist now. Those airports built on bay fill all over this country and the world will be underwater as well as the roads and rail that connect them to your homes. Unless we come to a common understanding of the very real long-term threats, your politicians will try to spend/waste/sink money into trying the impossible task of holding back the encroaching sea to "save" coastal cities and communities. Rising seas will create conflict and immense migration pressures similar to the Near East today. It is no wonder that our defense analysts call climate change our number one long term security threat.
All Americans need to admit to the problem of climate change so that as a country we can address the solutions as much and as soon as possible. If we do so, then future generations may hail us as the New Patriots who established the foundation for the continued success of our country into the future just as the vision and wisdom of the Founding Fathers laid a path for the last 200 years.

cosmosis

New Paltz, NY February 22, 2016

This is not surprising to reality-based citizens who have been paying attention.
And, with evidence showing how fossil-fuel interests privately acknowledged this potential decades ago, while privately financing a highly effective network of climate denial, one wonders whether they will be made to help pay the tens and tens of billions of dollars needed to strengthen coastal cities, and let's face it, relocate millions of people.
It sounds impossible now that the oil industry could be made to pay for its misdeeds but no one ever thought apartheid could end (somewhat) peacefully, nor that a Black American could be elected President in the early 21st century, until they happened. No one thought we could go to the moon, and then we did...The point is, we need to again do what people once thought impossible and we need to do it quickly. Luckily, it is not a job that requires new knowledge, only new investment. And where do we get the money? Further good news is the fact that investment in reducing climate change is actually a huge boon to the global economy. Let's get started people, unless there are those of you out there who actually thought Waterworld was a good movie...

Terry Schiff

Alpharetta Ga February 22, 2016

It is puzzling to find so many climate deniers asserting that 95% of climate scientists are wrong, using simplistic reasoning that is not supported by the incredible depth and breadth of research. Political scientists have been examining this phenomenon, and some have concluded that this stubborn denial is caused not by any lack of information. We cannot "educate" them out of their irrational beliefs. Their intransigence is caused by a desire for social cohesion with like minded persons.
In order to get everyone on the same page, we need to stop arguing about the science. There is nothing to argue about.
Instead we need to talk about solutions which are not political lightning rods in and of themselves. The fee and dividend approach to reducing carbon emissions is budget neutral, utilizes the free market to create technologies, and is budget neutral. This is a plan that everyone can get behind.
I just hope we can do the right thing sooner, rather than later.

  • Recommend

Scott

  • Flag
  • 2Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

CityBumpkin

Earth February 22, 2016

First, if you are talking about Holocene Deglaciation, I believe the estimated rate was about average of 1cm per year. A rise of 3ft (roughly 1 meter) over 85 years would be about 1.17 cm per year.

"Doesn't seem like much" ignores how dramatic the effect of Holocene Deglaciation had on global climate. The impact on human beings will be much greater now, given how densely human beings populate the world versus 12-14,000 years ago. We are not isolated groups of nomads who can just pick up and move. The changes will be very disruptive to our very complicated way of life.

I'm not sure what point you are getting at regarding the Triassic. I don't think any scientist is claiming human-made climate change is going to cause life on Earth to disappear. But the question is whether many existing species - including us - will make it through the change.

  • Flag
  • 3Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Mal Adapted

Oregon February 22, 2016

Bruise: "Can someone please explain why ocean levels rose 500 ft from 12,000-10,000 BC?"

If you really wanted to know, you could easily have found the answer by consulting any undergraduate geology text book, or any number of online government or academic sites.

One suspects you did not ask the question because you wanted to know the answer, however.

As for "something is not adding up with the main stream narrative": if you got your information from primary scientific sources rather than from science-denying blogs, you'd get a much clearer picture of the truth.

Look Ahead

is a trusted commenter WA February 22, 2016

While riding in a small tour boat well offshore in the Central American Pacific recently, I was struck by how hot the water spray was, like a warm shower. There is a lot of energy building up in the oceans, where storms originate, like the recent record breaking hurricane that happily slowed before striking the Mexico coast.

The problem of sea level rise will be magnified by huge storms, much sooner than 2100. Vulnerable areas like South Florida and the Keys, New Orleans, the Carolinas, New York and other major population areas are likely to experience flooding and wind damage on an unprecedented scale.

And climate denying politicians will be falling all over each other to rush trillions in Federal disaster money to the rescue.

James Wilson

is a trusted commenter Colorado February 22, 2016

Bruise is a troll who gets people to waste their time answering questions that s/he knows the answer to. I hope someone is paying him/her. For those others who might need an answer, google the Milankovitch cycles. Which, indeed do take a long, long time (in terms of the news cycle or the election cycle). Current changes are very fast compared to the transition from glacial to interglacial period. The Younger Dryas did feature some real rapid changes and the cause of those changes (some 13,000 years ago) will not comfort trolls who know that CO2 warms and caused the recent warming. The meltwater surge may have changed the ocean currents..... And now we are melting Greenland - (See GRACE data).
The occurrence of ice ages or the Younger Dryas does not prove that all climate change is natural. We know how much CO2 humans have added to the atmosphere since 1970 (for example) and we know how much climate warmed and how much energy that required. We know that added CO2 added more than enough energy to explain the observed warming. Its the 1st Law.
The "they just want a big government" trolls are amazing and, we hope, amusing. For the sake of our posterity, I hope that we take instruction from COP21 soon.

ferd

largo February 22, 2016

They estimate a rise of 3 to 4 feet by 2100- but they admit that the rise could be higher and faster because they don't know how fast and how much of the ice in West Antarctica will collapse and melt. But here's a hint- WA's likely to make significant contributions to sea level rise, and faster than many expect. As we yammer, it melts.

And sea level rise will NOT be a linear progression, one drip at a time- perhaps there could be a jump of one foot or more in a decade or two- and that would be VERY unpleasant.

drspock

New York February 22, 2016

The 3-4 feet are the most conservative estimates. The problem with making any reliable estimates is that the rate of warming and the rate of ice melt in Greenland and Antarctica have no precedent and so there are no good baselines for comparisons. Some estimates suggest 3 to 4 meters by 2100, which multiplies these numbers by a factor of three.

Maybe if the insurance industry weighs in after it figures out what their loses will be then GOP nay sayers will finally believe that we are really in trouble.

Lennerd

Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam February 22, 2016

Climate change alerting scientists in the 1970 rued sea level rises whose outside predictions for the year 2100 have already been met or exceeded. Arctic sea ice depletions fall into this category. The accelerating effects of ice melting, ocean temperature rise, and ocean acidification were all underestimated 40 years ago and are now provoking more exasperation among climate scientists. These are not projections based on computer models any more: they're facts on the ground for anyone not practicing willful ignorance to see.

Greenpa

“ 'I think we can definitely be confident that sea-level rise is going to continue to accelerate if there’s further warming, which inevitably there will be,' said Stefan Rahmstorf..."

The Times could easily simplify; and with full truth: "Rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and will continue to accelerate." It's life or death for millions of people. Gary Barnett

Elyria, Ohio February 22, 2016

Some of the ocean islands that are experiencing rising waters are not being swallowed by rising ocean levels. In fact they are sinking. The Earth's crust are divided into plates, the ocean plates are heavier than the continential plates and are diving below the lighter plates the continents are on. These ocean islands are on those diving ocean plates and are being pulled under the oceans surface. They only appear to be sinking. Plate tectonics in action.

  • Flag
  • 1Recommend

  • Flag
  • Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Alonzo quijana

Miami beach February 22, 2016

"They added that the flooding that is starting to make life miserable in many coastal towns — like Miami Beach...."

I live in Miami Beach and flooding is not making life miserable. For decades the city had some tidal flooding -- one to six inches pooling on a couple of blocks, i.e. "nuisance flooding" -- in April and October from spring tides, but even that's been remedied with a new flood control system, and raising some of the streets a few feet as in my bayside neighborhood. The Atlantic beach side of the islands are the highest parts of town and have no flooding at all.

Can't speak for the other areas, but the hyperbole does not fit the reality in Miami Beach.

  • Flag
  • 5Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Ecce Homo

Jackson Heights, NY February 22, 2016

If you enter "flooding in Miami Beach" into Google, you'll get 387,000 results. The very first one is a New Yorker article by Elizabeth Kolbert titled "The Siege of Miami" that begins like this:

"The city of Miami Beach floods on such a predictable basis that if, out of curiosity or sheer perversity, a person wants to she can plan a visit to coincide with an inundation."

There's another fun item from CBS TV, headlined "Miami Beach Residents Say They’re Tired Of Continued High Tide Flooding."

politicsbyeccehomo.wordpress.com

bl

You might try reading the cited PNAS article and accompanying references. You
might also profit from reading pertinent articles that address precisely
this subject, there are lots to choose from...

You might also ask yourself what you mean by "proof" and what type
of evidence would be required to constitute "proof". Do you mean
absolute 100% certainty? Do you mean lots and lots and still more
evidence of warming across the entire planet that is at least correlated
with very high levels of CO2 in the low level atmosphere...for which
theoretical explanations connect one to the other. What additional
evidence are you looking for that you cannot yet find in
the annals of peer reviewed science journals? It is not clear
to me what is the source of skepticism that obliges this request
for "more proof". Do you also need "more proof" before you
accept the need to reset the cost of carbon based energy and begin
biasing energy costs in favor or non carbon sources? Why is
that?

James Murray

CA February 22, 2016

Dr Hodes, your's is a case of willful ignorance at best. Here's an experiment you might try:
Take a trip any major city in Asia. Try Beijing, or Taipei, or Kaohsiung. Note the air quality. Stay awhile. Note (particularly in Kaohsiung) the plethora of motor scooters spewing blue exhaust. Observe that this exhaust goes into the atmosphere. Further observe that this activity is extremely widespread, is continues unabated 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 52 weeks a year.

Next reflect on the relative thinness Earth's atmosphere. Defining its ultimate extent can be somewhat arbitrary, so let's choose the boundary of the stratosphere, at ~30 miles. This is a small fraction of the ~8,000 mile diameter of our globe, ~ 0.4%.

You can object that 30 miles seems to be ample breathing room to accommodate a bit of air pollution. Yet I propose to you, dear sir, that if you can be rigorously honest and deeply contemplate - visualize - perhaps, using the real life, real-time examples of Beijing et. al. - the massive infusion of pollution in our vital air -- and further recognize that such activity is similarly, incessantly occurring in a multitude of cities across much of the globe . . . well, one HOPES you'll begin to see the reality at hand.

Then again, denial is a tough nut to crack, an in many cases can't be, with dire consequences. In this case, the consequence is a slow, steady march towards the mass suicide of our species.

  • 17Recommend

Mal Adapted

Oregon February 22, 2016

David S. Hodes, MD: "What I fail to see presented is proof that human activity plays a significant part in determining climate."

Why would you expect to see proof? Proof is for mathematicians and distillers. What climate science offers is varying levels of confidence. A lopsided majority of working climate scientists have high confidence that human activity is responsible for the warming trend of the last 50 years.

If you aren't familiar with the multiple lines of evidence for anthropogenic climate change yourself, you can either trust the consensus of experts or become an expert yourself. Failing both, you have no basis for an opinion one way or another.

bl

rochester February 22, 2016

You haven't yet distinguished between "proof" and what scientists
mean by "evidence" that strongly supports one hypothesis relative to another. What do you mean by "proof" in the context of this scientific subject? What do you want a "proof" to consist of or to say that is qualitatively different from what is present in scientific journals? For you
what are the differences between evidence and hypotheses?

Another way to think of this would seem to be to give a detailed answer to this question. In your detailed study of the literature, have you seen any reliable scientific evidence that anthropogenic activity is a significant, albeit not the only, factor in average temperature increases both in the atmosphere and on earth's surface. If you have not, what do you think it is that others are seeing in their measurements of different physical quantities over time that you are not seeing? More specifically, what are
your thoughts about Mann's work?

Do you agree that there has been an increase in C02 concentrations in the lower atmosphere? Do you think this is not
principally due to human generated activity? If not, what would that be? If you agree that CO2 concentration is higher now than
the past, do you agree that there has also been evidence of
increased warming all over the planet?

If your replies to these two questions are yes but this is not a proof,
I'd be interested to know what you think the response to the current situation should be?

  • Flag

CastleMan

Colorado February 23, 2016

Dr. Hodes, there is a vast body of scientific literature available that establishes that connection. It is not in doubt. You are a medical scientist and, having taken your share of classes in chemistry and maybe physics, are certainly aware of the basic physical principles that govern our atmosphere. You should not, therefore, be surprised that adding huge amounts of carbon dioxide, and lesser amounts of methane and other greenhouse gases, will cause the atmosphere to retain heat at lower altitudes.

  • Flag
  • 8Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

CastleMan

Colorado February 23, 2016

As you should be aware, being a medical scientist, there is never a situation in science where we claim one hundred percent certainty about a proposed answer to a question about nature. Even the most solidly-supported theories don't get that degree of affirmation. And, of course and, again, as you surely know, a proposed explanation of a natural phenomenon that has been confirmed repeatedly and independently by a variety of scientists is not a hypothesis. It is a theory and, as you certainly know, a theory is not a guess, a belief, a dogma, or an ideology. It is an explanation based on available evidence.

In the case of our atmosphere, the available evidence clearly indicates that human combustion of fossil fuels - oil and coal, mostly, but also natural gas - increases the concentration of greenhouse gas molecules in the atmosphere. Those molecules have the effect of limiting the capacity of radiation to "bounce" off the surface of the planet and return to space. Instead, the radiation (which comes to the planet from the Sun) is retained at low altitudes in the atmosphere.

It does not take the addition of much greenhouse gas, relative to the total amount of gases in the atmosphere, to cause a significant greenhouse effect. Depending on the particular greenhouse gas compound, the effect may be more or less long lasting (relatively speaking).

This webpage can help you understand the greenhouse effect: https://www.ucar.edu/learn/1_3_1.htm.

  • Flag
  • 3Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

Edwards

Toledo February 22, 2016

Ice ages are a result of the Milankovitch cycle, which are changes in the Earth's orbit and relative distance from the Sun. it would take too long to explain and even then you probably wouldn't understand it, but it's covered in any Introductory Astronomy class.

Sam

There can be multiple causes for climate change - just because the last big swing was caused by something else doesn't mean that that will be the cause every time. If you see an orange cat, it doesn't follow that every cat will always be orange.

Climate Scientists do a lot of work examining ancient climates and ancient climate change; it's not true that no one talks about this. It's all baked into the models already.

Michael Mills

Bruise--
Rising 3-5 feet in 100 years is approximately TWICE the rate as the end of the last ice age--according to your 500 feet in 2000 years figures. And the rate of melting is a positive feedback loop so it will be much faster than that in the coming centuries.
The RATE of temperature increase in the past 100 years is MUCH higher than at the end of the last ice age.

Alex

Don't you think climate scientists know about ice ages and associated big changes in sea level (it's even mentioned in this article)? Instead of inferring that everybody is missing or even hiding something big that you you just thought about, perhaps you should start by realizing that your own understanding is, necessarily, limited, and that implying that everybody else is wrong just because you don't understand something (as your comment does), is not the best way to approach these things.

izzy607

Portland.OR February 23, 2016

No, what they are saying is that the current, very rapid rise of global temperatures is caused by human burning of fossil fuels. Natural causes are accounted for in the climate research, and without the manmade compete global temps would be rising much more slowly, or not at all. Here is a simple metaphor--just because your house can burn down from natural causes, like a lightening strike, does not mean that if you deliberately set a fire in your house it will not burn down.

CityBumpkin

Earth February 22, 2016

"PC" is now code word for anything incompatible with a worldview shaped not by facts but by sheer ignorance.

Sea level rise is not the end-all-be-all of climate change. It is merely a measure of how much glaciated ice is melting, and is therefore a way to gauge the extent of climate change.

But let's say sea level rise is all there is. Did you serious think about your suggestion of "build sea walls" or "not building on low lying coastal land." First, climate change is cumulative and has a tendency to accelarate. Second, do you think uprooting major cities, many which are in coastal areas, will not have massive disruptive impact?

You are happy enough to look to science to find answers for engineering projects to fix the problem. Why would you bury your head in the sand when there is a scientific consensus on telling how to stop causing the problem in the first place.

maryland February 22, 2016

The Dutch spend as much as a percentage of GDP on their dikes as we spend on defense. They also are extremely concerned that if the rate of rise accelerates they will be unable to keep up and raise their defenses fast enough. In the US only a few places can possibly be defended due to the high cost so only the very most valuable cities, like NY, would get the high strong walls needed.

  • Flag
  • 70Recommend
  • Share this comment on FacebookShare this comment on Twitter

MDCooks8

West of the Hudson February 22, 2016

So if the Dutch are spending $30 billion a year, why shouldn't the US and other countries begin investing in technologies to "adapt" to rising waters , while at the same time continue invest in the technologies that will help reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

At some point (perhaps 100 years from now), the investments to reduce emissions will no longer have a positive impact reducing emissions but will level off (Law of Diminishing Returns) so be prudent begin transferring those funds in alternatives...
If all the eggs are in one basket.....

I think infrederick is too optimistic. No sea walls will save even New York for more than several decades. Read the article: sea level rise is expected to speed up after 2100. I've read another article: the real damage from today's greenhouse emissions will come over the next 1000 years and it will take 10,000 or more years after the end of industrial civilization to reverse it. I wish that were a human lifetime; then we might get some action; but it's not, and we won't. It's sad.

jbsay

PA February 23, 2016

The Dutch GDP is $50B they spend about $1B/year on dikes. That is 2% of GDP.
For that they protect the entire country - nearly all of which would be under water otherwise.
The IPCC predicts about 50cm of SLR - that is 2', but even at 4' very little of the US would be impacted.
A 2' Sea wall need neither be strong nor high, nor would very much of the US need it.
